   Differential-Neuts:76.6 %, Lymph:15.7 %, Mono:6.0 %, Eos:1.1 %, Lactic
   Acid:1.2 mmol/L, Albumin:2.2 g/dL, LDH:238 IU/L, Ca++:8.1 mg/dL,
   Mg++:1.9 mg/dL, PO4:4.5 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation and is now intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Per report, patient was demonstrating increased
   work of breathing in the ED with resp rates in the 30s.  No ABG done
   prior to intubation.  Patient does have a history of COPD and CHF with
   last ECHO showing EF of 35-40%.  On arrival to the ICU, patient was
   demonstrated large negative pressures with low PIPs around 12.  Initial
   ABG was actually venous and was 7.16/56/48.  Repeat just after
   increased tidal volumes, ABG was 7.22/43/302 on FiO2 100%.  Likely has
   increased dead space in the setting of hypovolemia and hypoperfusion as
   well.
   - Continue to titrate vent settings to achieve target minute
   ventilation as patient has component of respiratory acidosis in
   addition to non-AG metabolic acidosis
   - Will attempt to wean as acidosis improves
   - VAP precautions
   - Repeat CXR in am
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.
   - Will check Urine AG
   - Nutrition consult for TPN
   - Avoid NS for resuscitation given hyperchloremia and hypernatremia
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Tachycardia: Patient was noted to have tachycardia (afib vs ST vs
   MAT) during last admission which was treated with IV lopressor
   transitioned to PO lopressor.  A CTA at that time was negative for PE
   and CE ruled out MI.  Cardiology at that time felt that the rhythm was
   likely sinus tachy with APBs/MAT, and recommended watching as well as
   possibly initiating digoxin which was not started at that time.
   - Will cycle CE
   - Continue dilt gtt, will transition to home metoprolol as tolerated
   - IVF for dehydration
   - Continue to follow
   - Can discuss possible initiation of digoxin once ARF improves
   .
   # Hypernatremia: Has been ongoing for several days at rehab.  Unclear
   if patient has received more than 1L of free water as it is not
   documented in NH paperwork.
   - Calculated free water deficit is 2.8L
   - Will give D51/2NS now given dehydration and free water deficit
   - PM lytes
   - Urine lytes now
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Slightly decreased from
   prior.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional.  He was noted to be anemic with
   guaiac positive stools during last admission.  B12 and folate within
   normal limits.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Will send iron studies
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.
   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt
   started in ED
   - Continue coumadin 2.5 mg daily
   - Continue to trend INR
   - LUE US to rule out DVT at PICC site
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient appears dry on exam.  Likely
   pre-renal though may have a component of RTA or ATN as above.
   - Urine lytes
   - IVF resuscitation
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - Renally dose all meds
   .
   # Ruptured apendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  He is likely due
   to complete a course of flagyl/cipro in the next several days. Rec'd
   one dose of vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl
   - Will consult surgery for further recommendations regarding medical
   mgmt and abx course
   - As lactate wnl and patient appears dry with BP responding to fluid
   boluses, will continue cipro/flagyl for appendicitis as no other clear
   source of infection.  BPs currently normal
   - Low threshold to increase abx regimen should patient become unstable
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for now
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with heparin gtt, lansoprazole
   (is on omeprazole as o/p as well), bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line, need to confirm placement, PIV
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient
   .
   # Disposition: pending above
   .
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2107-4-21**] 04:30 PM
   PICC Line - [**2107-4-21**] 05:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:
   Disposition:

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male admitted to the ICU with hypernatremia, atrial fibrillation, and respiratory distress. He has a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, CHF, and ruptured appendix. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. He has a calculated free water deficit of 2.8L and is receiving IV fluids. The patient's laboratory results show anemia, hyperkalemia, and elevated troponin levels.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory acidosis and hypercapnia may worsen if the ventilator settings are not optimized.
2. Non-AG metabolic acidosis: The patient's acidosis may be due to saline resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure, or increased amino acids in TPN. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
3. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia may be due to atrial fibrillation, sinus tachycardia, or MAT. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may be due to dehydration, free water deficit, or other underlying conditions. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be due to chronic kidney disease, gastrointestinal bleeding, or other underlying conditions. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
6. Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient's right subclavian vein thrombosis may be due to central line placement or other underlying conditions. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
7. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury may be due to pre-renal azotemia, ATN, or RTA. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
8. Ruptured appendix: The patient's ruptured appendix may be due to appendicitis or other underlying conditions. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
9. Pancreatic mass: The patient's pancreatic mass may be due to pancreatic cancer or other underlying conditions. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to optimize ventilator settings to achieve target minute ventilation and improve respiratory acidosis.
2. Further evaluate the patient's non-AG metabolic acidosis to determine the underlying cause and develop a plan to correct it.
3. Monitor the patient's tachycardia and adjust therapy as needed to prevent complications.
4. Continue to manage the patient's hypernatremia and anemia with IV fluids, electrolyte replacement, and blood transfusions as needed.
5. Further evaluate the patient's right subclavian vein thrombosis to determine the underlying cause and develop a plan to prevent further complications.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust therapy as needed to prevent further kidney injury.
7. Continue to manage the patient's ruptured appendix with antibiotics and supportive care.
8. Further evaluate the patient's pancreatic mass to determine the underlying cause and develop a plan for further management.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation and is now intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16).   Patient was overbreathing
   the ventilator overnight when less sedated to increase pH and
   simultaneously driving down CO2.  Minute ventilation 12-17L/min.
   Patient has a history of COPD and likely chronically has a high CO2.
   Will not try to achieve his baseline CO2 currently as there is still an
   ongoing metabolic acidosis.
   - Continue to titrate vent settings to achieve target minute
   ventilation around 12-13 L/min
   - Will attempt to wean as acidosis improves
   - VAP precautions
   - Repeat CXR in am
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. some other occult
   infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC
   count.
   - Cont. cipro & flagyl
   - CT abdomen to examine for interval changes, worsening appendicitis
   vs. duodenal-pancreatic communication given low HCO3
   - f/u blood, urine, & sputum cultures
   - trend fever curve & WBC count.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Patient was noted to have tachycardia (afib vs ST vs
   MAT) during last admission which was treated with IV lopressor
   transitioned to PO lopressor.  A CTA at that time was negative for PE
   and CE ruled out MI.  Cardiology at that time felt that the rhythm was
   likely sinus tachy with APBs/MAT, and recommended watching as well as
   possibly initiating digoxin which was not started at that time.
   Patient has ruled out for an MI again.  Dilt drip stable at 10 mg/hr
   overnight with heart rates in the low 100s and SBP in the low 100s.
   Unable to transition to PO meds at this time as patient is NPO due to
   ruptured appendix.
   - Continue dilt gtt, titrate down as tolerated and transition to home
   metoprolol when able to take POs
   - Can discuss possible initiation of digoxin once ARF improves
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.
   - Switch to NaHCO3 for fluid resuscitation given hyperchloremia and
   hypernatremia
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: Has been ongoing for several days at rehab.  Unclear
   if patient has received more than 1L of free water as it is not
   documented in NH paperwork.
   - Calculated free water deficit is 2.8L
   - Patient received 0.5 L D51/2NS then 1.5L D5W overnight.
   - transition to D5W + 3amps NaHCO3 for IVF
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient appears dry on exam.  Likely
   pre-renal though may have a component of RTA or ATN as above.  FENa
   1.26%, so likely not entirely pre-renal.
   - IVF resuscitation
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - Renally dose all meds
   - nephrology consult
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Slightly decreased from
   prior.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional.  He was noted to be anemic with
   guaiac positive stools during last admission.  B12,  folate, & iron
   within normal limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase
   reactant and should be rechecked).  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT.  Cont. heparin gtt and hold
   coumadin as avoiding PO meds until further information from CT
   abdomen.
   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt
   started in ED
   .
   # Ruptured apendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  He is likely due
   to complete a course of flagyl/cipro in the next several days. Rec'd
   one dose of vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  Surgery
   recommended reimaging abdomen.
   - As lactate wnl and patient appears dry with BP responding to fluid
   boluses, will continue cipro/flagyl for appendicitis as no other clear
   source of infection.  BPs currently normal
   - Low threshold to increase abx regimen should patient become unstable
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for now, nutrition consult for
   TPN recs
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with heparin gtt, lansoprazole
   (is on omeprazole as o/p as well), bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line, need to confirm placement, PIV, will place A-line
   today
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, need to talk with HCP regarding patient
   overall status once further info from CT available.
   .
   # Disposition: pending above
   .

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation and is now intubated for respiratory failure. The patient has a fever, tachycardia, and non-AG metabolic acidosis. He has acute renal failure, anemia, and right subclavian vein thrombosis. The patient has a ruptured appendix, which is being medically managed with ciprofloxacin and metronidazole. He has a pancreatic mass and is on prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to his underlying COPD, atrial fibrillation, and profound metabolic acidosis.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and tachycardia may indicate sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and death.
3. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen due to his underlying chronic kidney disease, dehydration, and nephrotoxic medications.
4. Heart Failure: The patient's atrial fibrillation and tachycardia may worsen his underlying heart failure, leading to cardiogenic shock.
5. Ruptured Appendix: The patient's ruptured appendix may lead to peritonitis, abscess formation, and sepsis if not properly managed.
6. Venous Thromboembolism: The patient's right subclavian vein thrombosis may lead to pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis if not properly treated.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen due to his underlying chronic kidney disease, bleeding, or nutritional deficiencies.
8. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's non-AG metabolic acidosis may worsen due to his underlying chronic kidney disease, respiratory failure, or other underlying medical conditions.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's respiratory failure, sepsis, acute kidney injury, heart failure, ruptured appendix, venous thromboembolism, anemia, and metabolic acidosis require immediate attention. The patient should be closely monitored for signs of worsening respiratory failure, sepsis, and organ dysfunction. The patient's antibiotic regimen should be adjusted based on the results of his cultures and the patient's clinical response. The patient's fluid management should be optimized to prevent further dehydration and acidosis. The patient's nutritional status should be closely monitored, and the patient should be considered for total parenteral nutrition (TPN) if necessary. The patient's cardiac status should be closely monitored, and the patient should be considered for cardiology consultation if necessary. The patient's pancreatic mass should be followed up with imaging studies to monitor for any changes.

   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation and is now intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16).   Patient was overbreathing
   the ventilator overnight when less sedated to increase pH and
   simultaneously driving down CO2.  Minute ventilation 12-17L/min.
   Patient has a history of COPD and likely chronically has a high CO2.
   Will not try to achieve his baseline CO2 currently as there is still an
   ongoing metabolic acidosis.
   - Continue to titrate vent settings to achieve target minute
   ventilation around 12-13 L/min
   - Will attempt to wean as acidosis improves
   - VAP precautions
   - Repeat CXR in am
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. some other occult
   infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC
   count.
   - Cont. cipro & flagyl
   - CT abdomen to examine for interval changes, worsening appendicitis
   vs. duodenal-pancreatic communication given low HCO3
   - f/u blood, urine, & sputum cultures
   - trend fever curve & WBC count.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Patient was noted to have tachycardia (afib vs ST vs
   MAT) during last admission which was treated with IV lopressor
   transitioned to PO lopressor.  A CTA at that time was negative for PE
   and CE ruled out MI.  Cardiology at that time felt that the rhythm was
   likely sinus tachy with APBs/MAT, and recommended watching as well as
   possibly initiating digoxin which was not started at that time.
   Patient has ruled out for an MI again.  Dilt drip stable at 10 mg/hr
   overnight with heart rates in the low 100s and SBP in the low 100s.
   Unable to transition to PO meds at this time as patient is NPO due to
   ruptured appendix.
   - Continue dilt gtt, titrate down as tolerated and transition to home
   metoprolol when able to take POs
   - Can discuss possible initiation of digoxin once ARF improves
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.
   - Switch to NaHCO3 for fluid resuscitation given hyperchloremia and
   hypernatremia
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: Has been ongoing for several days at rehab.  Unclear
   if patient has received more than 1L of free water as it is not
   documented in NH paperwork.
   - Calculated free water deficit is 2.8L
   - Patient received 0.5 L D51/2NS then 1.5L D5W overnight.
   - transition to D5W + 3amps NaHCO3 for IVF
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient appears dry on exam.  Likely
   pre-renal though may have a component of RTA or ATN as above.  FENa
   1.26%, so likely not entirely pre-renal.
   - IVF resuscitation
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - Renally dose all meds
   - nephrology consult
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Slightly decreased from
   prior.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional.  He was noted to be anemic with
   guaiac positive stools during last admission.  B12,  folate, & iron
   within normal limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase
   reactant and should be rechecked).  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT.  Cont. heparin gtt and hold
   coumadin as avoiding PO meds until further information from CT
   abdomen.
   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt
   started in ED
   .
   # Ruptured apendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  He is likely due
   to complete a course of flagyl/cipro in the next several days. Rec'd
   one dose of vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  Surgery
   recommended reimaging abdomen.
   - As lactate wnl and patient appears dry with BP responding to fluid
   boluses, will continue cipro/flagyl for appendicitis as no other clear
   source of infection.  BPs currently normal
   - Low threshold to increase abx regimen should patient become unstable
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for now, nutrition consult for
   TPN recs
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with heparin gtt, lansoprazole
   (is on omeprazole as o/p as well), bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line, need to confirm placement, PIV, will place A-line
   today
   .
   # Code: Full
   .

   overall status once further info from CT available.
   .

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation and is now intubated for respiratory failure. The patient has a history of chronic CO2 retention and is likely experiencing respiratory failure due to IVF, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and profound metabolic acidosis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to a combination of factors, including IVF, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and profound metabolic acidosis. The patient's history of COPD and chronic CO2 retention may also contribute to his respiratory failure.
2. Fever: The patient's fever may be due to worsening of his ruptured appendicitis, aspiration pneumonitis from intubation, or an occult infectious process. The patient's WBC count is not elevated, which suggests that the fever may not be due to an infection.
3. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia may be due to atrial fibrillation, sinus tachycardia, or MAT. The patient has been ruled out for an MI, and his heart rate has been stable on diltiazem.
4. Non-AG Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may be due to saline resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure, increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA. The patient's urine lytes with anion gap suggest that the acidosis is not due to a simple anion gap metabolic acidosis.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may be due to a combination of factors, including inadequate free water administration, hyperchloremia, and hypernatremia.
6. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may be due to pre-renal causes, such as hypovolemia, or post-renal causes, such as obstruction. The patient's FENa is 1.26%, which suggests that the renal failure is not entirely pre-renal.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be due to a combination of factors, including chronic kidney disease, gastrointestinal bleeding, and iron deficiency.
8. Right Subclavian Vein Thrombosis: The patient's right subclavian vein thrombosis may be due to a combination of factors, including central venous catheter placement, hypercoagulability, and immobility.
9. Ruptured Appendicitis: The patient's ruptured appendicitis may be due to a combination of factors, including appendiceal obstruction, inflammation, and perforation.
10. Pancreatic Mass: The patient's pancreatic mass may be due to a combination of factors, including pancreatic cancer, pancreatitis, or a pancreatic pseudocyst.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's assessment and plan will depend on the results of his CT abdomen and the management of his respiratory failure, fever, tachycardia, and hypernatremia. The patient will require continued monitoring and management of his respiratory failure, fever, and hypernatremia. He will also require further evaluation and management of his tachycardia, non-AG metabolic acidosis, and anemia. The patient's pancreatic mass will require further evaluation and management, and he will require ongoing management of his right subclavian vein thrombosis.

s HR has gone up, now

d yesterday. [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim checked (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL.

   count and has been afebrile x 24 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a complex medical history, including lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR) and is now intubated for respiratory failure. The patient has undergone several interventions, including the placement of an arterial line, central line, and peripheral intravenous (PIV) line.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. The ABG results indicate a mixed acid-base disorder, with a pH of 7.34 and a PCO2 of 36 mmHg.
* Hemodynamics: The patient has AFib with RVR, which is likely due to a septic state. The mixed venous O2 saturation is high, suggesting distributive shock.
* Fever: The patient has been febrile, with a temperature of 37.7°C (99.8°F). The source of the fever is unclear, but it may be related to the ruptured appendicitis, aspiration pneumonitis, or an occult infectious process.
* Renal failure: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, with a creatinine level of 2.0 mg/dL. The fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) is 1.26%, suggesting that the renal failure is likely pre-renal in origin.
* Anemia: The patient has a baseline anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.1 g/dL. The anemia is likely related to chronic kidney disease (CKD) and may be partially dilutional.
* Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient has significant erythema and edema of the right upper extremity (RUE), which is consistent with a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient is receiving heparin therapy and will be started on coumadin for bridge therapy.
* Ruptured appendicitis: The patient has been medically managed with antibiotics and is likely due to complete a course of treatment in the next several days. The patient has been afebrile and has no leukocytosis.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient may continue to experience respiratory failure, which could worsen if the underlying cause is not addressed.
* Sepsis: The patient's febrile response may be indicative of an occult infectious process, which could lead to sepsis if not treated promptly.
* Renal failure: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure may worsen if the underlying cause is not addressed.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if the underlying cause is not addressed.
* DVT: The patient's DVT may lead to pulmonary embolism (PE) if not treated promptly.
* Fungemia: The patient's suspicion of fungemia may lead to sepsis if not treated promptly.

Recommendations:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as necessary.
* Continue to manage the patient's fever and sepsis with antibiotics and other supportive measures.
* Continue to manage the patient's renal failure with fluid resuscitation and other supportive measures.
* Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and adjust treatment as necessary.
* Consider adding anticoagulation therapy to prevent DVT and PE.
* Consider adding antifungal therapy to treat suspected fungemia.
* Continue to monitor the patient's DVT and adjust treatment as necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a complex medical history, including lung cancer, prostate cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and chronic heart failure (CHF). He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR) and is now intubated for respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation, with a trial of pressure support ventilation (PSV) to wean off the ventilator.
* Hemodynamics: The patient has AFib with RVR, which is likely due to septic shock. He has a mixed venous O2 saturation of 73%, suggesting distributive shock. His heart rate is persistently in the 130s, and he requires pressor support for blood pressure management.
* Fever: The patient has been febrile, with a temperature of 37.7°C (99.8°F). His white blood cell count is normal, and he has been afebrile for 24 hours. The cause of his fever is unclear, but it may be related to aspiration pneumonitis, occult infection, or worsening of his ruptured appendicitis.
* Non-AG metabolic acidosis: The patient's acid-base status has improved, but he still has a mild non-anion gap metabolic acidosis. The differential diagnosis includes saline resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure, increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level has normalized, but he will require close monitoring and judicious use of normal saline to prevent re-accumulation.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's kidney function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL. He has a component of pre-renal azotemia, but may also have a component of tubular damage or acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
* Anemia: The patient has a mild anemia, which is partially dilutional due to his chronic kidney disease (CKD).
* Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient has a significant erythema and edema of his right upper extremity, which is consistent with a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He has been started on heparin and coumadin, but his INR is subtherapeutic.
* Ruptured appendicitis: The patient has a history of ruptured appendicitis, which was medically managed with antibiotics. He is likely due to complete a course of antibiotics in the next few days.
* Pancreatic mass: The patient has a pancreatic mass, which has been stable on repeat imaging.

The patient's current medications include:

* Antibiotics: Vanc/Zosyn, Cipro/Flagyl
* Pressors: Levophed, Norepinephrine
* Sedatives: Fentanyl, Midazolam
* Heparin: Subcutaneous heparin, IV heparin
* Anticoagulants: Coumadin
* Anti-fungal medication: Fluconazole
* Antacid: Lansoprazole
* Bowel regimen: Not specified

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* Complete Blood Count (CBC): WBC 9.1 x 10^9/L, Hct 28.2%, Plt 348 x 10^9/L
* Electrolytes: Na 142 mmol/L, K 4.0 mmol/L, Cl 103 mmol/L
* Renal function: Creatinine 1.8 mg/dL, BUN 27 mg/dL
* Liver function: AST 26 IU/L, ALT 46 IU/L
* Lipid profile: Not specified
* Blood cultures: Not specified

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Mechanical ventilation with a trial of pressure support ventilation (PSV)
* Antibiotics: Vanc/Zosyn, Cipro/Flagyl
* Pressors: Levophed, Norepinephrine

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation and is now intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16).   Patient was overbreathing
   the ventilator overnight when less sedated to increase pH and
   simultaneously driving down CO2.  Minute ventilation 12-17L/min.
   Patient has a history of COPD and likely chronically has a high CO2.
   Will not try to achieve his baseline CO2 currently as there is still an
   ongoing metabolic acidosis.
   - Continue to titrate vent settings to achieve target minute
   ventilation around 12-13 L/min
   - Will attempt to wean as acidosis improves
   - VAP precautions
   - Repeat CXR in am
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. some other occult
   infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC
   count.
   - Cont. cipro & flagyl
   - CT abdomen to examine for interval changes, worsening appendicitis
   vs. duodenal-pancreatic communication given low HCO3
   - f/u blood, urine, & sputum cultures
   - trend fever curve & WBC count.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Patient was noted to have tachycardia (afib vs ST vs
   MAT) during last admission which was treated with IV lopressor
   transitioned to PO lopressor.  A CTA at that time was negative for PE
   and CE ruled out MI.  Cardiology at that time felt that the rhythm was
   likely sinus tachy with APBs/MAT, and recommended watching as well as
   possibly initiating digoxin which was not started at that time.
   Patient has ruled out for an MI again.  Dilt drip stable at 10 mg/hr
   overnight with heart rates in the low 100s and SBP in the low 100s.
   Unable to transition to PO meds at this time as patient is NPO due to
   ruptured appendix.
   - Continue dilt gtt, titrate down as tolerated and transition to home
   metoprolol when able to take POs
   - Can discuss possible initiation of digoxin once ARF improves
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.
   - Switch to NaHCO3 for fluid resuscitation given hyperchloremia and
   hypernatremia
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: Has been ongoing for several days at rehab.  Unclear
   if patient has received more than 1L of free water as it is not
   documented in NH paperwork.
   - Calculated free water deficit is 2.8L
   - Patient received 0.5 L D51/2NS then 1.5L D5W overnight.
   - transition to D5W + 3amps NaHCO3 for IVF
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient appears dry on exam.  Likely
   pre-renal though may have a component of RTA or ATN as above.  FENa
   1.26%, so likely not entirely pre-renal.
   - IVF resuscitation
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - Renally dose all meds
   - nephrology consult
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Slightly decreased from
   prior.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional.  He was noted to be anemic with
   guaiac positive stools during last admission.  B12,  folate, & iron
   within normal limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase
   reactant and should be rechecked).  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT.  Cont. heparin gtt and hold
   coumadin as avoiding PO meds until further information from CT
   abdomen.
   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt
   started in ED
   .
   # Ruptured apendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  He is likely due
   to complete a course of flagyl/cipro in the next several days. Rec'd
   one dose of vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  Surgery
   recommended reimaging abdomen.
   - As lactate wnl and patient appears dry with BP responding to fluid
   boluses, will continue cipro/flagyl for appendicitis as no other clear
   source of infection.  BPs currently normal
   - Low threshold to increase abx regimen should patient become unstable
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for now, nutrition consult for
   TPN recs
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with heparin gtt, lansoprazole
   (is on omeprazole as o/p as well), bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line, need to confirm placement, PIV, will place A-line
   today
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, need to talk with HCP regarding patient
   overall status once further info from CT available.
   .
   # Disposition: pending above
   ICU Care

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a complex medical history, including lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and a ruptured appendix. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation and is now intubated for respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a target minute ventilation of 12-13 L/min. His CO2 levels are elevated, and he has a history of COPD. The plan is to continue to titrate vent settings and attempt to wean as acidosis improves.
* Fever: The patient's fever may be related to worsening appendicitis, aspiration pneumonitis from intubation, or an occult infectious process. The plan is to continue antibiotics, CT abdomen to examine for interval changes, and trend fever curve and WBC count.
* Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia may be related to atrial fibrillation, SVT, or MAT. The plan is to continue diltiazem drip and titrate down as tolerated, and transition to metoprolol when able to take POs.
* Non-AG metabolic acidosis: The differential includes saline resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure, increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA. The plan is to switch to NaHCO3 for fluid resuscitation and continue to trend.
* Hypernatremia: The patient has been hypernatremic for several days and has received 0.5 L D51/2NS and 1.5 L D5W overnight. The plan is to transition to D5W + 3 amps NaHCO3 for IVF.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient appears dry on exam and likely has a pre-renal component, although may have a component of RTA or ATN. The plan is to continue IVF resuscitation, avoid nephrotoxins, and obtain a nephrology consult.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely related to CKD, although may be partially dilutional. The plan is to continue to trend and active T&S.
* Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient has significant erythema and edema of the RUE and has been on lovenox since admission. The plan is to continue heparin gtt and hold coumadin as avoiding PO meds until further information from CT abdomen.
* Ruptured appendicitis: The patient has been on Cipro/Flagyl since last admission and is likely due to complete a course of antibiotics. The plan is to continue antibiotics and re-image the abdomen as needed.
* Pancreatic mass: The patient has a pancreatic mass that has been stable on repeat imaging. The plan is to follow up with an outpatient appointment.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: Prolonged mechanical ventilation, respiratory acidosis, and pneumonia.
2. Fever: Sepsis, septic shock, and organ dysfunction.
3. Tachycardia: Cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.
4. Non-AG metabolic acidosis: Lactic acidosis, hyperkalemia, and cardiac arrhythmias.
5. Hypernatremia: Dehydration, seizures, and central pontine myelinolysis.
6. Acute on chronic renal failure: Acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease progression, and electrolyte imbalance.
7. Anemia: Blood transfusion reactions, bleeding complications, and cardiovascular instability.
8. Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and post-thrombotic syndrome.
9. Ruptured appendicitis: Perforated appendicitis, abscess formation, and sepsis.
10. Pancreatic mass: Pancreatitis, pancreatic duct obstruction, and pancreatic cancer progression.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan accordingly to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a complex medical history. The patient has been experiencing fever, hypotension, and respiratory distress, and has been treated with antibiotics, vasopressors, and mechanical ventilation. The patient's laboratory results indicate chronic kidney disease, hypernatremia, and acidosis. The patient's medical history includes atrial fibrillation, deep vein thrombosis, and sepsis without organ dysfunction.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis without organ dysfunction may progress to septic shock, which can lead to organ failure and death.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure may worsen, leading to respiratory arrest and death.
3. Renal Failure: The patient's chronic kidney disease may worsen, leading to acute kidney injury and further compromise the patient's ability to recover.
4. Deep Vein Thrombosis: The patient's deep vein thrombosis may embolize, leading to pulmonary embolism and further complications.
5. Acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may worsen, leading to further organ dysfunction and death.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may lead to central pontine myelinolysis, a potentially fatal condition.
7. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen, leading to further cardiac complications and death.
8. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient's impaired skin integrity may lead to further complications, such as infection and necrosis.
9. Nutritional Deficiencies: The patient's nutritional deficiencies may worsen, leading to further complications and decreased ability to recover.
10. Medication Errors: The patient's complex medication regimen may lead to medication errors, which can have serious consequences.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely to detect any changes or complications early.
2. Adjust the patient's medication regimen as needed to manage their symptoms and prevent complications.
3. Consider consulting with a nephrologist to optimize the patient's renal function and prevent further complications.
4. Consider consulting with a cardiologist to optimize the patient's cardiac function and prevent further complications.
5. Consider consulting with a nutritionist to optimize the patient's nutritional intake and prevent further complications.
6. Consider consulting with an infectious disease specialist to optimize the patient's antibiotic regimen and prevent further complications.
7. Continue to provide aggressive supportive care, including mechanical ventilation and vasopressors, as needed.
8. Consider performing further diagnostic tests, such as echocardiography and lung biopsy, to further evaluate the patient's condition and guide treatment.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ruptured appendix and recurrent hypotension with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (A-Fib with RVR). He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with respiratory failure, sepsis, atrial fibrillation, DVT, and acidosis/acute renal failure.

The patient's condition is complex, and potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is on mechanical ventilation, and weaning may be challenging due to his underlying condition and the risk of respiratory acidosis.
2. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis, and the source of the infection is unclear. He is at risk of developing organ dysfunction and mortality if not properly treated.
3. Atrial fibrillation: The patient has persistent atrial fibrillation, which can lead to hemodynamic instability, heart failure, and stroke.
4. DVT: The patient has extensive DVT, and there is a risk of pulmonary embolism if not properly anticoagulated.
5. Acidosis/acute renal failure: The patient has pre-renal azotemia, and there is a risk of acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease if not properly managed.
6. Cardiovascular instability: The patient has persistent hypotension, and there is a risk of cardiac arrest if not properly managed.
7. Neurological complications: The patient is sedated, and there is a risk of neurological complications such as seizures, coma, and brain death if not properly monitored.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of ruptured appendix, and there is a risk of gastrointestinal complications such as perforation, bleeding, and infection if not properly managed.
9. Infectious complications: The patient is at risk of developing secondary infections, such as pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and bloodstream infections, if not properly managed.
10. Cardiovascular surgery: The patient may require cardiovascular surgery to address his underlying condition, which carries risks such as bleeding, infection, and mortality.

Based on the patient's condition, the following plan of care is recommended:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and weaning as tolerated.
2. Continue antibiotics for sepsis and cover for fungal infection.
3. Monitor atrial fibrillation and consider cardioversion for persistent and refractory hypotension.
4. Continue anticoagulation for DVT and monitor for signs of pulmonary embolism.
5. Continue treatment for acidosis and acute renal failure.
6. Monitor cardiovascular stability and consider invasive monitoring if necessary.
7. Monitor neurological status and consider sedation reversal if necessary.
8. Monitor gastrointestinal status and consider surgical consultation if necessary.
9. Monitor for infectious complications and consider antibiotic stewardship.
10. Consider cardiovascular surgery if necessary.

The patient's family should be updated regularly on his condition, and code status should be discussed with them. The patient's code status is currently set to full code, but this should be reviewed and updated as necessary.

   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and is now intubated for respiratory
   failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). ABG much better now
   - Trial of PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent.
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat high suggestive of distributive shock. [**Month (only) 11**] also have a
   component of cardiogenic shock, however, given pt
s HR has gone up, now
   persistently in 130s. + pressor requirement for BP support. Dilt gtt
   was d/c
d yesterday. [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim checked (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL.
   - Consider trial of phenylephrine instead of levophed to eliminate
   positive chronotropy
   - Consider adding oral BBker for rate control
   - Consider chemical cardioversion with amio
   - PE unlikely given pt has been on lovenox, now on heparin gtt.
   - Can discuss possible initiation of digoxin once ARF improves
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. some other occult
   infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC
   count and has been afebrile x 24 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a
   robust inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically
   ill state.
   - Abx switched to Vanc/Zosyn yesterday given decompensation.
   - Add fluconazole for empiric coverage of fungal (stop TPN while
   getting treated for ?fungemia)
   - Surveillance blood cultures
   - CT negative for any drainable abscesses.
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: resolved. Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.  Got
   bicarb with IVF yesterday
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: resolved.
   - monitor
   - judicious use of normal saline
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient now adequately fluid
   resuscitated.  Likely pre-renal though may have a component of RTA or
   ATN as above.  FENa 1.26%, so likely not entirely pre-renal.
   - appreciate nephrology recs
   - renally dose meds
   .

   guaiac positive stools during last admission.  B12,  folate, & iron
   within normal limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase
   reactant and should be rechecked).  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as

   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and is now intubated for respiratory
   failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). ABG much better now
   - Trial of PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent.
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat high suggestive of distributive shock. [**Month (only) 11**] also have a
   component of cardiogenic shock, however, given pt
s HR has gone up, now
   persistently in 130s. + pressor requirement for BP support. Dilt gtt
   was d/c
d yesterday. [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim checked (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL.
   - Consider trial of phenylephrine instead of levophed to eliminate
   positive chronotropy
   - Consider adding oral BBker for rate control
   - Consider chemical cardioversion with amio
   - PE unlikely given pt has been on lovenox, now on heparin gtt.
   - Can discuss possible initiation of digoxin once ARF improves
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. some other occult
   infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC
   count and has been afebrile x 24 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a
   robust inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically
   ill state.
   - Abx switched to Vanc/Zosyn yesterday given decompensation.
   - Add fluconazole for empiric coverage of fungal (stop TPN while
   getting treated for ?fungemia)
   - Surveillance blood cultures
   - CT negative for any drainable abscesses.
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: resolved. Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.  Got
   bicarb with IVF yesterday
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: resolved.
   - monitor
   - judicious use of normal saline
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient now adequately fluid
   resuscitated.  Likely pre-renal though may have a component of RTA or
   ATN as above.  FENa 1.26%, so likely not entirely pre-renal.
   - appreciate nephrology recs
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Slightly decreased from
   prior.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional.  He was noted to be anemic with
   guaiac positive stools during last admission.  B12,  folate, & iron
   within normal limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase
   reactant and should be rechecked).  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT.  Cont. heparin gtt and hold
   coumadin as avoiding PO meds until further information from CT
   abdomen.
   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt
   started in ED
   .
   # Ruptured apendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  He is likely due
   to complete a course of flagyl/cipro in the next several days. Rec'd
   one dose of vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  Surgery
   recommended reimaging abdomen.
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn for broad spectrum coverage in the absence
   of specific microbio data
   - appreciate [**Doctor First Name **] recs
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for now, hold TPN while
   +suspicion of fungemia.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with heparin gtt, lansoprazole
   (is on omeprazole as o/p as well), bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line, A-line, PIV. Likely needs a fem line given the
   number of IV medications pt is receiving.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix, who was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with RVR, and is now intubated for respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated for respiratory failure, which is likely due to a combination of IVF, atrial fibrillation with RVR, and profound metabolic acidosis.
* Hemodynamics: The patient has atrial fibrillation with RVR, which is likely due to a septic state. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation with RVR in the past.
* Fever: The patient has been on antibiotics for medical management of a ruptured appendicitis, and his fever may represent worsening of this process or aspiration pneumonitis from intubation.
* Non-AG metabolic acidosis: The patient's non-AG metabolic acidosis has resolved, but the differential diagnosis includes saline resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure, increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia has resolved, but he will need to be monitored and judiciously given normal saline.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, which is likely pre-renal, but may have a component of RTA or ATN. The patient will need to be renally dosed and will require nephrology recommendations.
* Anemia: The patient has anemia, which is likely due to chronic kidney disease, and will need to be trended and actively treated.
* Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient has significant erythema and edema of the right upper extremity, and will need to be continued on heparin gtt and hold coumadin until further information from CT abdomen.
* Ruptured appendicitis: The patient has ruptured appendicitis, which is being medically managed with antibiotics, and will need to complete a course of flagyl/cipro in the next several days.
* Pancreatic mass: The patient has a pancreatic mass, which is being followed as an outpatient.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Worsening of respiratory failure
* Development of septic shock
* Further deterioration of renal function
* Progression of atrial fibrillation with RVR
* Development of fungemia
* Complications related to the ruptured appendicitis, such as abscess formation or perforation
* Complications related to the pancreatic mass, such as bleeding or obstruction

The patient requires continued ICU-level care, including close monitoring of his respiratory, hemodynamic, and renal status. He will also require ongoing management of his antibiotics, anticoagulation, and electrolytes.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix, who was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with RVR. He is currently intubated for respiratory failure and has been diagnosed with septic shock, acute kidney injury, and non-AG metabolic acidosis. He also has a ruptured appendicitis, which is being medically managed, and a right subclavian vein thrombosis.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 38°C (100.4°F)
* Heart rate: 118 bpm
* Blood pressure: 95/56 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 13 inspirations per minute
* SpO2: 98%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CVP 24 mmHg, MAP 65 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 9.8 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 27.9%
* Platelet count: 372 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL
* Bicarbonate: 16 mmol/L
* Glucose: 115 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.7 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.2 g/dL
* LDH: 238 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.1 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.5 mg/dL

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Cardiac complications: Given the patient's history of atrial fibrillation with RVR and septic shock, there is a risk of cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiogenic shock.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory failure and non-AG metabolic acidosis may lead to further respiratory distress, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and respiratory failure.
3. Renal complications: The patient's acute kidney injury and non-AG metabolic acidosis may lead to further kidney damage, acute tubular necrosis (ATN), and chronic kidney disease (CKD).
4. Infectious complications: The patient's ruptured appendicitis and septic shock may lead to further infections, such as pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and bacteremia.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's ruptured appendicitis and septic shock may lead to further gastrointestinal complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, and obstruction.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient's right subclavian vein thrombosis and septic shock may lead to further coagulopathy, including disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, I recommend the following:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and hemodynamic status closely.
2. Maintain the patient's respiratory support, including mechanical ventilation and non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV).
3. Continue to manage the patient's septic shock, including administration of antibiotics, vasopressors, and fluid resuscitation.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and electrolyte levels closely, and consider dialysis if necessary.
5. Consider further imaging studies to rule out other potential causes of the patient's condition, such as a pulmonary embolism or aortic dissection.
6. Consider consulting with a gastroenterologist to further evaluate and manage the patient's ruptured appendicitis and potential gastrointestinal complications.
7. Consider consulting with a cardiologist to further evaluate and manage the patient's atrial fibrillation and potential cardiac complications.

   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and is now intubated for respiratory
   failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). ABG much better now
   - Trial of PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent.
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat high suggestive of distributive shock. [**Month (only) 11**] also have a
   component of cardiogenic shock, however, given pt
s HR has gone up, now
   persistently in 130s. + pressor requirement for BP support. Dilt gtt
   was d/c
d yesterday. [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim checked (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL.
   - Continue chemical cardioversion with amio
   - PE unlikely given pt has been on lovenox, now on heparin gtt.
   - Can discuss possible initiation of digoxin once ARF improves
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. some other occult
   infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC
   count and has been afebrile x 24 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a
   robust inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically
   ill state.
   - Abx switched to Vanc/Zosyn yesterday given decompensation.
   - Surveillance blood cultures
   - CT negative for any drainable abscesses.
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   - ID denied Fluconazole
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: resolved. Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.  Got
   bicarb with IVF yesterday
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: resolved.
   - monitor
   - judicious use of normal saline
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient now adequately fluid
   resuscitated.  Likely pre-renal though may have a component of RTA or
   ATN as above.  FENa 1.26%, so likely not entirely pre-renal.
   - appreciate nephrology recs
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Slightly decreased from
   prior.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional.  He was noted to be anemic with
   guaiac positive stools during last admission.  B12,  folate, & iron
   within normal limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase
   reactant and should be rechecked).  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT.  Cont. heparin gtt and hold
   coumadin as avoiding PO meds until further information from CT
   abdomen.
   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt
   started in ED
   .
   # Ruptured apendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  He is likely due
   to complete a course of flagyl/cipro in the next several days. Rec'd
   one dose of vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  Surgery
   recommended reimaging abdomen.
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn for broad spectrum coverage in the absence
   of specific microbio data
   - appreciate [**Doctor First Name **] recs
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for now, hold TPN while
   +suspicion of fungemia.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with heparin gtt, lansoprazole
   (is on omeprazole as o/p as well), bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line, A-line, PIV. Likely needs a fem line given the
   number of IV medications pt is receiving.
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, HCP [**Name (NI) 4955**] [**Name (NI) 4961**] (neighbor; number in
   chart)
   .

Based on the progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a complex medical history, including lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix. He is currently intubated for respiratory failure and has atrial fibrillation with RVR.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38°C (100.4°F)
* Heart rate: 118 bpm (107-155 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 95/56 mmHg (70/48-110/66 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 13 inspirations per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 98%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CVP 24 mmHg, mean arterial pressure 95 mmHg

The patient's lab results show:

* WBC: 9.8 K/uL
* Hct: 27.9%
* Plt: 372 K/uL
* Cr: 1.8 mg/dL
* TCO2: 16 mmol/L
* Glucose: 115 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.7 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.2 g/dL
* LDH: 238 IU/L
* Ca++: 7.1 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.2 mg/dL
* PO4: 3.5 mg/dL

The patient has several potential medical complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to a combination of IVF, atrial fibrillation with RVR, and profound metabolic acidosis.
2. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's hemodynamic instability is likely due to septic shock, cardiogenic shock, and distributive shock.
3. Fever: The patient's fever may be due to worsening of his ruptured appendix, aspiration pneumonitis from intubation, or an occult infectious process.
4. Non-AG metabolic acidosis: The patient's non-AG metabolic acidosis may be due to saline resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure, increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may be due to inadequate fluid resuscitation.
6. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure may be due to pre-renal, RTA, or ATN.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be due to baseline anemia, partially dilutional, or related to CKD.
8. Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient's right subclavian vein thrombosis may be due to central venous catheter placement or underlying thrombophilia.
9. Ruptured appendix: The patient's ruptured appendix may be due to inadequate medical management or delayed surgical intervention.

The patient requires continued close monitoring and management of his respiratory, hemodynamic, and metabolic status. He also requires further evaluation and management of his underlying medical conditions, including his ruptured appendix and right subclavian vein thrombosis.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications are identified:

Summary:

The patient is a 66-inch tall individual who has been admitted to the ICU with atrial fibrillation (AFib), sepsis without organ dysfunction, and chronic renal failure. The patient has been experiencing fever, hypertension, and tachycardia. The patient's respiratory status has been stable, but the patient has required mechanical ventilation. The patient's laboratory results have shown evidence of metabolic acidosis, hypernatremia, and impaired liver function.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Atrial fibrillation may lead to stroke, heart failure, or cardiac arrest.
	* Tachycardia may exacerbate cardiac workload and increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Respiratory Complications:
	* Acute respiratory failure may progress to chronic respiratory failure, requiring long-term mechanical ventilation.
	* Pneumonia or other respiratory infections may develop, exacerbating respiratory failure.
3. Renal Complications:
	* Chronic renal failure may worsen, leading to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) or the need for dialysis.
	* Acute kidney injury may develop, further compromising renal function.
4. Sepsis Complications:
	* Sepsis may progress to septic shock, organ dysfunction, or death.
	* Bacterial or fungal infections may develop, leading to sepsis or septicemia.
5. Neurological Complications:
	* Impaired skin integrity may lead to pressure ulcers, infections, or sepsis.
	* Neurological dysfunction may develop, including altered mental status, seizures, or stroke.
6. Gastrointestinal Complications:
	* Stress ulcer may develop, leading to gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation.
	* Malnutrition or inadequate nutrition may exacerbate the patient's underlying conditions.
7. Venous Complications:
	* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) may lead to pulmonary embolism (PE) or post-thrombotic syndrome.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent or mitigate these potential complications.

1. Acute respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status has deteriorated, with a plateau pressure of 14 cmH2O and a respiratory system compliance of 70, indicating a high risk of further respiratory decline.
2. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's pH is 7.35, indicating a metabolic acidosis, which may be contributing to the patient's tachycardia and hypertension.
3. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is 139 mg/dL, indicating hypernatremia, which may be contributing to the patient's tachycardia and hypertension.
4. Chronic renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is 1.7 mg/dL, indicating chronic renal failure, which may be contributing to the patient's electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
5. Sepsis: The patient's white blood cell count is 11.0 K/uL, indicating an active infection, which may be contributing to the patient's tachycardia and hypertension.
6. Deep venous thrombosis (DVT): The patient has a DVT in the upper extremity, which may be contributing to the patient's tachycardia and hypertension.
7. Atrial fibrillation (AFib): The patient's heart rhythm remains in AFib, which may be contributing to the patient's tachycardia and hypertension.
8. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's skin is not assessed, but the patient's temperature is 38°C, indicating a high risk of skin breakdown.
9. Fever: The patient has a temperature of 38°C, indicating a high risk of infection.
10. Hyperglycemia: The patient's glucose level is 156 mg/dL, indicating hyperglycemia, which may be contributing to the patient's tachycardia and hypertension.

The patient's medications include amiodarone, midazolam, heparin, and norepinephrine, which may be contributing to the patient's tachycardia and hypertension.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38°C (100.4°F)
* Heart rate: 118 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 95/56 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 13 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 98%

The patient's laboratory results indicate:

* White blood cell count: 11.0 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.7 mg/dL
* Sodium: 139 mg/dL
* Potassium: 4.5 mEq/L
* Chloride: 115 mEq/L
* Bicarbonate: 16 mEq/L
* Glucose: 156 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.7 mmol/L

Based on the patient's condition and laboratory results, the patient requires close monitoring and aggressive treatment to prevent further complications. The patient's respiratory status requires close monitoring, and the patient's metabolic acidosis and hypernatremia require prompt correction. The patient's chronic renal failure requires ongoing management, and the patient's sepsis requires prompt antibiotic treatment. The patient's DVT requires anticoagulation therapy, and the patient's AFib requires cardioversion.

   Assessment and Plan
   81 yo male with history of ruptured appendicitis now re-admitted with
   hypotension consistent with sepsis but have not been able to clearly
   identify new source.  He has had significant improvement with
   Amiodarone in regards to heart rate and although cardioversion failed
   he has had improved heart rate control and occasional sinus beats.
   1)Shock--Likely combined sepsis and cardiogenic contribution and will
   Rx as-->
   Sepsis--Continue with broad spectrum ABX and PRN fluid
   bolus-_Vanco/ZOsyn
definative source of recurrent infection not clearly
   Levophed to wean and Vasopressin to wean off
   A-Fib--Continue with amiodarone
   and->will attempt to provide wean of levophed as primary measure to
   evaluate improvement in hemodynamics.
   2)Respiratory Failure-Patient with good tolerance of decreased in PSV
   and having minimal secretions and actually opening eyes to voice.  Most
   challenging issue is persistent tachycardia, persistent hypotension.
   Secretions minimal
   -SBT this morning
   -Check ABG at 30 minutes
   -Will need to check anesthesia notes as to difficulty of airway.
   -metabolic issues (acidosis), possible pulmonary edema, poor mental
   status are all barriers that must be considered.
   3)Acute Renal Failure-he does have stable creatinine across time
   -Will provide HCO3- as needed for acidosis should HCO3- decrease below
   16
   -Appreciate renal input
   -Will renal dose all medications
   4)Atrial Fibrillation-
   _Failed cardioversion
   -Continue Amiodarone
   -Hope for SR conversion
   5)Thrombosis-DVT
   -Continue with Heparin
   -To Coumadin when stable
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: TPN to continue with bowel rest
   Glycemic Control:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male admitted to the ICU with sepsis, hypotension, and atrial fibrillation. The patient's condition has been unstable, with multiple attempts at cardioversion failing to convert the patient's heart rhythm to sinus rhythm.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 38°C (100.4°F)
* Heart rate: 106 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 95/60 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 28 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 98%
* Central venous pressure (CVP): 17 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results indicate:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 9.8-11.0 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit (Hct): 27.9-25.8%
* Platelet count (Plt): 372-378 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.8-2.0 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 18-20 mg/dL
* Glucose: 115-156 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.7 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.2 g/dL
* LDH: 238 IU/L
* Calcium (Ca++): 7.5 mg/dL
* Magnesium (Mg++): 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus (PO4): 3.6 mg/dL

The patient's fluid analysis shows:

* pH: 7.35
* PaCO2: 33 mmHg
* PaO2: 116 mmHg
* HCO3-: 20 mmol/L
* Base excess: -6 mmol/L

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Shock: The patient has likely combined sepsis and cardiogenic shock, and will be treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and PRN fluid boluses.
* Sepsis: The patient will continue to receive broad-spectrum antibiotics and will have fluid boluses as needed.
* Respiratory failure: The patient will continue to receive mechanical ventilation and will have his respiratory status closely monitored.
* Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine has been stable, and will receive HCO3- as needed for acidosis.
* Atrial fibrillation: The patient will continue to receive amiodarone and will be monitored for potential conversion to sinus rhythm.
* Thrombosis: The patient will continue to receive heparin and will be transitioned to coumadin when stable.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Continued sepsis and septic shock
* Cardiogenic shock
* Respiratory failure
* Acute renal failure
* Atrial fibrillation with potential for stroke or cardiac arrest
* Thrombosis, including deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE)
* Metabolic acidosis
* Pulmonary edema
* Poor mental status
* Airway complications, including difficulty intubating or extubating the patient.

Based on the patient's condition, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and respiratory and cardiac status. The patient's treatment plan should be adjusted as necessary to address any complications that arise.

   The NG tube tip is in the stomach. The bilateral pleural effusions are
