   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). Was not extubated last night
   due to hemodynamic instability. Needs
   - Trial of PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Try RSBI and SBT,
   if favorable, extubate later today
   - Issues that could complicate extubation: mental status (very sedated)
   and minute volume requirement required to compensate for metabolic
   acidosis.
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Cardiology was consulted last night;
   recommended digoxin loading.
   - Continue chemical cardioversion with amio, digoxin (dose by level
   given ARF)
   - Wean levophed as tolerated by MAP > 65
   - f/u cardiology recs
   - consider repeating echo
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. some other occult
   infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC
   count and has been afebrile x 48 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a
   robust inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically
   ill state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. There is a concern
   for fungal infection given pt
s prolonged abx course and frequent
   hospital stays.
   - Abx switched to Vanc/Zosyn [**4-23**] given decompensation. (Day 3 today)
   - Surveillance blood cultures
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   - ID denied empiric fluconazole; will f/u glucan and galactomannin and
   re-assess once data available.
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: resolved. Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.  Got
   bicarb with IVF yesterday
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: was resolving, however borderline high again in the
   setting of restarting tube feeds.
   - increase free water boluses
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient now adequately fluid
   resuscitated.  Likely pre-renal though may have a component of RTA or
   ATN as above.  FENa 1.26%, so likely not entirely pre-renal.
   - F/u nephrology recs
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Slightly decreased from
   prior.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional.  He was noted to be anemic with
   guaiac positive stools during last admission.  B12,  folate, & iron
   within normal limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase
   reactant and should be rechecked).  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT.
   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt
   started in ED
   - Transition to coumadin if extubated
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  He is likely due
   to complete a course of flagyl/cipro in the next several days. Rec'd
   one dose of vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  Surgery
   recommended reimaging abdomen.
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn for broad spectrum coverage in the absence
   of specific microbio data
   - [**Doctor First Name 3**] recs: OK to feed
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for now, TF/po intake post
   extubation
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with heparin gtt, lansoprazole
   (is on omeprazole as o/p as well), bowel regimen
   .

 will pull when hemodynamically stable),

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a complex medical history, including lung cancer, prostate cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), and chronic kidney disease (CKD). He was admitted with hypernatremia and AFib with RVR, and was intubated for respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient remains intubated due to hemodynamic instability and requires a trial of pressure support ventilation (PSV) to anticipate weaning off the ventilator.
* Hemodynamics: The patient has AFib with RVR, which is likely due to septic shock. He has a mixed venous O2 saturation of 98%, suggesting distributive shock. Although he may have a component of cardiogenic shock, he did not show much benefit from dopamine or metoprolol. Cardiology was consulted and recommended loading with digoxin.
* Fever: The patient's fever may be related to worsening of his ruptured appendicitis, aspiration pneumonitis from intubation, or an occult infectious process. He was switched to vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn) due to decompensation, and surveillance blood cultures were ordered.
* Non-AG metabolic acidosis: The patient's acidosis has resolved, and his differential diagnosis includes saline resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure, increased amino acids in total parenteral nutrition (TPN), or renal tubular acidosis (RTA).
* Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia is resolving, but is still borderline high due to restarting tube feeds. He will require increased free water boluses and close monitoring.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient is now adequately fluid resuscitated, and his acute kidney injury (AKI) is likely pre-renal with a component of RTA or acute tubular necrosis (ATN). He will require renal dose medications and follow-up with nephrology.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to chronic kidney disease, and he will require ongoing monitoring and treatment.
* Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient has a significant erythema and edema of his right upper extremity, and will require continued heparin therapy and close monitoring.
* Ruptured appendicitis: The patient's appendicitis is medically managed, and he will require completion of his antibiotic course.
* Pancreatic mass: The patient's pancreatic mass is being followed as an outpatient, and appears to have been stable on repeat imaging.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if he is not extubated and weaned off the ventilator.
* Hemodynamic instability: The patient's hemodynamic instability may worsen if his cardiac function does not improve.
* Infection: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count may indicate an infection, which could worsen if not treated promptly.
* Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen if he does not receive adequate fluid resuscitation and treatment.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of guaiac-positive stools and anemia may indicate a risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, which could worsen if not monitored closely.
* Deep vein thrombosis: The patient's right subclavian vein thrombosis may worsen if not treated promptly, and may increase his risk of pulmonary embolism.

   The NG tube tip is in the stomach. The bilateral pleural effusions are
   moderate to large. The study is extremely limited due to the patient's
   head
   overlying right upper lung. Overall little change compared to the prior
   study.
   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). Was not extubated last night
   due to hemodynamic instability. Needs
   - Trial of PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Try RSBI and SBT,
   if favorable, extubate later today
   - Issues that could complicate extubation: mental status (very sedated)
   and minute volume requirement required to compensate for metabolic
   acidosis.
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Cardiology was consulted last night;
   recommended digoxin loading.
   - Continue chemical cardioversion with amio, digoxin (dose by level
   given ARF)
   - Wean levophed as tolerated by MAP > 65
   - f/u cardiology recs
   - consider repeating echo
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. some other occult
   infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC
   count and has been afebrile x 48 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a
   robust inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically
   ill state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. There is a concern
   for fungal infection given pt
s prolonged abx course and frequent
   hospital stays.
   - Abx switched to Vanc/Zosyn [**4-23**] given decompensation. (Day 3 today)
   - Surveillance blood cultures
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   - ID denied empiric fluconazole; will f/u glucan and galactomannin and
   re-assess once data available.
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: resolved. Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.  Got
   bicarb with IVF yesterday
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: was resolving, however borderline high again in the
   setting of restarting tube feeds.
   - increase free water boluses to 150 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient now adequately fluid
   resuscitated. FENa 1.26%, so likely not entirely pre-renal.
   - F/u nephrology recs
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Currently in the high20s,
   stable x 3+ days.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional (LOS 14.5L positive).
   He was noted to be anemic with guaiac positive stools during last
   admission.  B12,  folate, & iron  within normal limits (though ferritin
   may be elevated as an acute phase reactant and should be rechecked).
   [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT.
   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt
   started in ED
   - Warfarin started yesterday for bridging.
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  Rec'd one dose of
   vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  CT abdomen showing
   no drainable fluid collection
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn for broad spectrum coverage in the absence
   of specific microbio data
   - [**Doctor First Name 3**] recs: OK to feed; TF started yesterday [**4-24**]
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, TF started yesterday
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with heparin gtt and warfarin,
   lansoprazole (is on omeprazole as o/p as well), bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from last admission), A-line, R fem CVC [**4-23**]
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, HCP [**Name (NI) 4955**] [**Name (NI) 4961**] (neighbor; number in
   chart); will speak with HCP again today or tomorrow to give update.
   .

Based on the progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a complex medical history, including lung cancer, prostate cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR), and chronic kidney disease (CKD). He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with RVR, and was intubated for respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure. The ventilator settings are CMV/ASSIST/AUTOFLOW, with a tidal volume (Vt) of 500 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has atrial fibrillation with RVR, which is likely due to septic shock. He has a history of atrial fibrillation with RVR in the past. The mixed venous oxygen saturation (SvO2) is high, suggesting distributive shock. The patient did not respond well to dopamine and metoprolol, and was started on amiodarone and digoxin for cardiac management.
* Renal: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, with a baseline creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL. He is currently on hemodialysis and has a urine output of 2,035 mL.
* Hemodynamics: The patient's mean arterial pressure (MAP) is 65 mmHg, and his central venous pressure (CVP) is 13 mmHg. He is receiving levophed and metoprolol to manage his blood pressure.
* Infectious: The patient has a history of ruptured appendicitis and is currently on ciprofloxacin and flagyl for medical management. He has a fever of 38.2°C, and his white blood cell count (WBC) is 11.0 x 10^9/L.
* Metabolic: The patient has a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, which is likely due to saline resuscitation, diarrhea, or renal failure. He is receiving bicarbonate supplementation and has a normal anion gap.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is 139 mmol/L, and he is receiving free water boluses to manage his hypernatremia.
* Anemia: The patient has a baseline hemoglobin level of 37 g/dL, and is currently anemic. He is receiving iron supplementation and has a normal ferritin level.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and may require further respiratory support.
* Cardiovascular instability: The patient has atrial fibrillation with RVR, and may require further management of his cardiac status.
* Renal failure: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, and may require further renal replacement therapy.
* Infection: The patient has a history of ruptured appendicitis and is currently on antibiotics for medical management. He may be at risk for further infection.
* Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, and may require further management of his acid-base status.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is 139 mmol/L, and may require further management of his hypernatremia.
* Anemia: The patient is anemic, and may require further management of his anemia.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, the following plan is recommended:

* Continue respiratory support with mechanical ventilation.
* Monitor the patient's cardiac status and manage his atrial fibrillation with RVR.
* Continue renal replacement therapy and monitor the patient's renal function.
* Monitor the patient for signs of infection and manage his antibiotics accordingly.
* Monitor the patient's acid-base status and manage his metabolic acidosis accordingly.
* Monitor the patient's sodium level and manage his hypernatremia accordingly.
* Monitor the patient's anemia and manage his anemia accordingly.
* Continue to trend the patient's laboratory results and adjust his management plan accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with multiple comorbidities. The patient's condition has remained stable, with no significant changes in vital signs or laboratory values. However, the patient's heart rate remains tachycardic, and blood pressure has been unstable, requiring frequent boluses of fluids and levophed.

The patient's medications include vancomycin, amiodarone, metoprolol, and digoxin, which may interact with each other and increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias. The patient's cardiac status is complicated by atrial fibrillation, which may be contributing to their tachycardia.

The patient's respiratory status is also concerning, with a high respiratory rate and low oxygen saturation. They are receiving mechanical ventilation and require frequent adjustments to their ventilator settings.

The patient's renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 2.0 mg/dL. They have chronic kidney disease and are receiving renal replacement therapy.

The patient's laboratory values are concerning, with elevated lactate levels, decreased albumin levels, and elevated liver enzymes. These values may indicate a high risk of sepsis and organ dysfunction.

Potential medical complications that may arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's medications, particularly amiodarone and digoxin, may increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, which could lead to cardiac arrest or stroke.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is concerning, and they may require further adjustments to their ventilator settings or intubation.
3. Sepsis: The patient's laboratory values indicate a high risk of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and mortality.
4. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is impaired, and they may require further renal replacement therapy or dialysis.
5. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's laboratory values indicate a high risk of metabolic acidosis, which could lead to further complications and mortality.

To manage these potential complications, the patient should be closely monitored for any changes in their condition and receive targeted interventions to address their specific needs. This may include adjustments to their medications, ventilator settings, and renal replacement therapy.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 66-inch tall individual with a weight not specified, who is admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of sepsis without organ dysfunction, respiratory failure, acute, and chronic renal failure. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, and is currently on various medications including levophed, amiodarone, and metoprolol.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.8°C (98.3°F) and 36.4°C (97.6°F) at different times
* Heart rate: 119 beats per minute (bpm) with a range of 106-136 bpm
* Blood pressure: 89/53 mmHg and 76/50 mmHg at different times
* Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute (bpm)
* SpO2: 98%
* Heart rhythm: Atrial fibrillation

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 11.0 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 8.7 g/dL
* Platelet count: 380 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.9 mg/dL
* Sodium: 129 mmol/L
* Potassium: 4.4 mmol/L
* Glucose: 104 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination shows:

* General appearance: No acute distress
* Cardiovascular: Irregular heartbeat, tachycardic
* Respiratory: Clear breath sounds, scattered rhonchi
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present, distended
* Extremities: Both upper extremities markedly swollen, right arm oozing transudative fluid
* Skin: Warm
* Neuro: Not following commands, winces to painful stimuli

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Acidosis, metabolic
* Deep venous thrombosis (DVT), upper extremity
* Sepsis without organ dysfunction
* Fever (hypothermia, pyrexia, not fever of unknown origin)
* Hypernatremia (high sodium)
* Renal failure, chronic (chronic kidney disease)
* Atrial fibrillation
* Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)
* Impaired skin integrity

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Nutrition: Nutren Renal (Full) at 30 mL/hour
* Glycemic control: Monitoring of blood glucose levels
* Lines: PICC line, arterial line, and multi-lumen line
* Prophylaxis: DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP
* Medications: Levophed, amiodarone, metoprolol, and others
* Cardiology consultation: Load with digoxin 250 mg IV, then 125 mg IV QOD, and check level on [**4-26**] and dose by level. If pressure improves, consider metoprolol 2.5 mg IV and/or reloading amio.
* ECHO for CHF: Considered due to prolonged length of stay (>14 days).

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's condition include:

* Cardiac complications: Atrial fibrillation, tachycardia, and cardiac arrest
* Respiratory complications: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), pneumonia, and respiratory failure
* Renal complications: Acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease progression, and electrolyte imbalances
* Infectious complications: Sepsis, pneumonia, and urinary tract infections
* Cardiovascular complications: Deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and cardiac arrhythmias
* Neurological complications: Seizures, stroke, and encephalopathy
* Gastrointestinal complications: Gastrointestinal bleeding, pancreatitis, and bowel obstruction

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and is now intubated for respiratory
   failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). ABG much better now
   - Trial of PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent.
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat high suggestive of distributive shock. [**Month (only) 11**] also have a
   component of cardiogenic shock, however, given pt
s HR has gone up, now
   persistently in 130s. + pressor requirement for BP support. Dilt gtt
   was d/c
d yesterday. [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim checked (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL.
   - Continue chemical cardioversion with amio
   - Wean levophed as tolerated by MAP > 65
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. some other occult
   infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC
   count and has been afebrile x 24 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a
   robust inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically
   ill state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses.
   - Abx switched to Vanc/Zosyn [**4-23**] given decompensation.
   - Surveillance blood cultures
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   - ID denied empiric fluconazole
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: resolved. Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.  Got
   bicarb with IVF yesterday
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: resolved.
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient now adequately fluid
   resuscitated.  Likely pre-renal though may have a component of RTA or
   ATN as above.  FENa 1.26%, so likely not entirely pre-renal.
   - F/u nephrology recs
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Slightly decreased from
   prior.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional.  He was noted to be anemic with
   guaiac positive stools during last admission.  B12,  folate, & iron
   within normal limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase
   reactant and should be rechecked).  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.

The patient is currently intubated for respiratory failure, and his hemodynamic status is unstable, with a heart rate in the 130s and a blood pressure that is difficult to maintain. He has a mixed venous oxygen saturation of 27.1%, which is suggestive of distributive shock.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 11.0, a hemoglobin level of 8.7 g/dL, and a platelet count of 380 K/uL. His electrolyte levels are abnormal, with a sodium level of 139 mmol/L, a potassium level of 4.4 mmol/L, and a chloride level of 118 mmol/L.

The patient has a number of potential medical complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated for respiratory failure, and his oxygen saturation is 98%. He has a mixed venous oxygen saturation of 27.1%, which is suggestive of distributive shock.
2. Cardiac failure: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation with RVR, and his heart rate is in the 130s. He has a mixed venous oxygen saturation of 27.1%, which is suggestive of distributive shock.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a fever, and his white blood cell count is elevated. He has a history of ruptured appendix and is receiving antibiotics for suspected sepsis.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient has a creatinine level of 2.0 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 19 mmol/L, which is suggestive of acute kidney injury.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose level is 104 mg/dL, which is elevated.
6. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is 8.7 g/dL, which is low.
7. Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient has a thrombus in his right subclavian vein, which is causing swelling and erythema in his right upper extremity.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Respiratory support: The patient is intubated for respiratory failure, and his oxygen saturation is being monitored.
2. Cardiovascular support: The patient is receiving vasopressors to maintain his blood pressure, and his heart rate is being monitored.
3. Antibiotic therapy: The patient is receiving antibiotics for suspected sepsis.
4. Fluid management: The patient is receiving fluid resuscitation to maintain his blood pressure.
5. Nutritional support: The patient is receiving nutritional support through a nasogastric tube.
6. Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's hemodynamic status is being closely monitored to ensure that his blood pressure and heart rate are stable.
7. Electrolyte management: The patient's electrolyte levels are being closely monitored to ensure that they are within normal ranges.
8. Renal support: The patient is receiving renal support through dialysis.
9. Pain management: The patient is receiving pain management through the use of analgesics.

The patient's prognosis is guarded due to his complex medical history and unstable hemodynamic status. He requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and improve his outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix, who was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with RVR. He was intubated for respiratory failure and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient has a prolonged ICU stay, with multiple comorbidities and complex medical issues.

Current status:

* Respiratory failure: The patient remains intubated due to hemodynamic instability. A trial of pressure support ventilation (PSV) is planned to wean off the ventilator.
* Hemodynamics: The patient has atrial fibrillation with RVR, likely due to septic shock. Cardiology was consulted, and digoxin loading was recommended.
* Fever: The patient's fever may be related to worsening of the ruptured appendicitis, aspiration pneumonitis, or an occult infectious process. Antibiotics were switched to vancomycin and Zosyn, and surveillance blood cultures are pending.
* Non-AG metabolic acidosis: The patient's acidosis has resolved, and the differential diagnosis includes saline resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure, increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are borderline high again, likely due to restarting tube feeds. Free water boluses will be increased to monitor.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's kidney function is likely pre-renal, with a component of RTA or ATN. Renal dosing of medications will be continued, and nephrology recommendations will be followed.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely related to chronic kidney disease, with a possible component of acute phase reactant. Iron, B12, and folate levels are within normal limits.
* Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient has a significant erythema and edema of the right upper extremity, with a subtherapeutic INR. Heparin will be continued, and coumadin will be transitioned if the patient is extubated.
* Ruptured appendicitis: The patient has been medically managed with Cipro and flagyl, and is likely due to complete a course of antibiotics in the next several days. Surgery recommended reimaging the abdomen.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: Prolonged mechanical ventilation, respiratory acidosis, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.
* Hemodynamic instability: Cardiac arrhythmias, hypotension, and cardiac arrest.
* Sepsis: Worsening of the ruptured appendicitis, aspiration pneumonitis, or an occult infectious process.
* Renal failure: Acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and electrolyte imbalances.
* Anemia: Chronic kidney disease, acute phase reactant, and iron deficiency.
* Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Pulmonary embolism, deep vein thrombosis, and septic emboli.
* Pancreatic mass: Pancreatitis, pancreatic abscess, and pancreatic cancer progression.

Recommendations:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation as needed.
* Manage the patient's hemodynamics with digoxin and heparin, and consider repeating an echocardiogram.
* Continue antibiotics for the ruptured appendicitis and consider switching to a different antibiotic if the patient's condition worsens.
* Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust fluid management accordingly.
* Continue to trend the patient's anemia and consider iron supplementation if necessary.
* Monitor the patient's right subclavian vein thrombosis and consider transitioning to coumadin if extubated.
* Continue to follow the patient's pancreatic mass and consider imaging studies to monitor for progression.

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male admitted to the ICU with sepsis, atrial fibrillation, and respiratory failure. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 117 bpm and blood pressure of 109/64 mmHg. He has a history of ruptured appendicitis and is currently receiving antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy. His respiratory status is stable, with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 403. His laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, creatinine, and lactate levels, indicating ongoing sepsis. He is also receiving sedation and analgesia to manage his pain and agitation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to continue, and there is a risk of organ dysfunction or failure if not properly managed.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if he is not able to tolerate extubation, which could lead to further complications such as pneumonia or respiratory arrest.
3. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may persist, and there is a risk of stroke or systemic embolization if not properly managed.
4. Venous Thrombosis: The patient's venous thrombosis may worsen if not properly managed with anticoagulation therapy, which could lead to pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis.
5. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may worsen if not properly managed, which could lead to further complications such as cardiac arrhythmias or respiratory failure.
6. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding may worsen if not properly managed, which could lead to further complications such as hypovolemic shock or respiratory failure.
7. Infection: The patient may develop a secondary infection, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infection, which could worsen his condition and lead to further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to manage the patient's sepsis with antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider extubation if possible.
3. Manage the patient's atrial fibrillation with anticoagulation therapy and consider cardioversion if necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's venous thrombosis closely and consider adjusting anticoagulation therapy as necessary.
5. Manage the patient's metabolic acidosis with bicarbonate therapy and consider adjusting his fluid and electrolyte management as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal bleeding closely and consider adjusting his anticoagulation therapy as necessary.
7. Consider obtaining a repeat echocardiogram to assess the patient's cardiac function and to guide further management.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). Was not extubated yesterday
   due to pH 7.19 after one hour on PS.
   - Continue trials of PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Try RSBI
   and SBT
   - Issues that could complicate extubation: mental status (very sedated)
   and minute volume requirement required to compensate for metabolic
   acidosis.
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Cardiology was consulted last night;
   recommended digoxin loading.
   - Continue chemical cardioversion with amio, digoxin (dose by level
   given ARF)
   - Wean levophed as tolerated by MAP > 65
   - f/u cardiology recs
   - repeat  echo pending
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. other occult infectious
   process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC count and
   has been afebrile x 48 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a robust
   inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically ill
   state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. There is a concern for
   fungal infection given pt
s prolonged abx course and frequent hospital
   stays. Yeast in urine and sputum. MRSA screen pos.
   - C. diff negative [**4-25**]
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn started [**4-23**] given initial decompensation. (Day 4
   today)
   - Surveillance blood cultures - NGTD
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   - ID denied empiric fluconazole; will f/u glucan and galactomannin and
   re-assess once data available.
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis. Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.  Has
   received Bicarb. Likely to improve with diuresis.
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: was resolving, however borderline high again in the
   setting of restarting tube feeds.
   - increase free water boluses to 250 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure:  Cr stable at 1.8
 2.0. Patient now
   adequately fluid resuscitated. FENa 1.26%, so likely not entirely
   pre-renal. Maintaining good UOP.
   - F/u nephrology recs
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Currently in the high20s,
   stable x 3+ days.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional (LOS 15.5L positive).
   He was noted to be anemic with guaiac positive stools during last
   admission.  B12,  folate, & iron  within normal limits (though ferritin
   may be elevated as an acute phase reactant and should be rechecked).
   [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT. INR therapeutic at 2.1.
   - Cont warfarin
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  Rec'd one dose of
   vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  CT abdomen showing
   no drainable fluid collection
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn Day [**7-17**] (started [**4-21**]) for broad spectrum
   coverage in the absence of specific microbio data
   - [**Doctor First Name 3**] recs: OK to feed; TF started [**4-24**]
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, TF with incr free water flushes
   .

   and SBT
   - Issues that could complicate extubation: mental status (very sedated)
   and minute volume requirement required to compensate for metabolic
   acidosis.
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim

   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. other occult infectious
   process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC count and
   has been afebrile x 48 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a robust
   inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically ill
   state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. There is a concern for
   fungal infection given pt
s prolonged abx course and frequent hospital

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix, who was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR). He was intubated for respiratory failure and has been receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient has a prolonged course of antibiotics, including vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam, for a suspected fungal infection.

Current Status:

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 106 bpm, and blood pressure of 98/53 mmHg. His oxygen saturation is 100% on 40% FiO2. His respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute and a tidal volume of 400 mL. His cardiac status is stable, with a normal cardiac rhythm and a normal cardiac output.

Potential Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he may require continued mechanical ventilation to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's blood pressure is borderline low, and he may require further fluid resuscitation to maintain adequate perfusion.
3. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is stable, but he may require further monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is stable, but he may require further transfusions to maintain adequate hemoglobin levels.
5. Thrombosis: The patient has a history of thrombosis, and he may require further anticoagulation therapy to prevent further thrombotic events.
6. Infection: The patient has a suspected fungal infection, and he may require further antibiotics and antifungal therapy to prevent further progression.
7. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, which may require further management to prevent further acidosis.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient will continue to receive mechanical ventilation and will be monitored closely for any changes in his respiratory status. He will also receive further anticoagulation therapy to prevent further thrombotic events. The patient's anemia will be monitored and managed as necessary. The patient's suspected fungal infection will be further evaluated and treated as necessary. The patient's metabolic acidosis will be managed with further fluid resuscitation and electrolyte management.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). Was not extubated yesterday
   due to pH 7.19 after one hour on PS.
   - Continue trials of PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Try RSBI
   and SBT
   - Issues that could complicate extubation: mental status (very sedated)
   and minute volume requirement required to compensate for metabolic
   acidosis.
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Cardiology was consulted last night;
   recommended digoxin loading.
   - Continue chemical cardioversion with amio, digoxin (dose by level
   given ARF)
   - Wean levophed as tolerated by MAP > 65
   - f/u cardiology recs
   - repeat  echo pending
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. other occult infectious
   process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC count and
   has been afebrile x 48 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a robust
   inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically ill
   state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. There is a concern for
   fungal infection given pt
s prolonged abx course and frequent hospital
   stays. Yeast in urine and sputum. MRSA screen pos.
   - C. diff negative [**4-25**]
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn started [**4-23**] given initial decompensation. (Day 4
   today)
   - Surveillance blood cultures - NGTD
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   - ID denied empiric fluconazole; will f/u glucan and galactomannin and
   re-assess once data available.
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis. Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.  Has
   received Bicarb.
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: was resolving, however borderline high again in the
   setting of restarting tube feeds.
   - increase free water boluses to 250 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure:  Cr stable at 1.8
 2.0. Patient now
   adequately fluid resuscitated. FENa 1.26%, so likely not entirely
   pre-renal. Maintaining good UOP.
   - F/u nephrology recs
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Currently in the high20s,
   stable x 3+ days.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional (LOS 15.5L positive).
   He was noted to be anemic with guaiac positive stools during last
   admission.  B12,  folate, & iron  within normal limits (though ferritin
   may be elevated as an acute phase reactant and should be rechecked).
   [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT.
   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt
   started in ED
   - Cont warfarin for bridging.
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  Rec'd one dose of
   vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  CT abdomen showing
   no drainable fluid collection
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn for broad spectrum coverage in the absence
   of specific microbio data
   - [**Doctor First Name 3**] recs: OK to feed; TF started [**4-24**]
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, TF with incr free water flushes
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with heparin gtt and warfarin,
   lansoprazole, bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from last admission), A-line, R fem CVC [**4-23**]
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, HCP [**Name (NI) 4955**] [**Name (NI) 4961**] (neighbor; number in
   chart); will speak with HCP again today or tomorrow to give update.
   .
   # Disposition: requires ICU level of care

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a complex medical history, including lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, atrial fibrillation, and chronic kidney disease. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation in the ICU.

The patient's current conditions include:

* Non-oliguric renal failure with acute tubular necrosis (ATN)
* Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR)
* Metabolic acidosis
* Hypernatremia
* Acute on chronic renal failure
* Anemia
* Right subclavian vein thrombosis
* Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed
* Pancreatic mass

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

* Acute kidney injury (AKI) progression
* Cardiac arrhythmias and potential for cardiac arrest
* Respiratory failure and potential for prolonged mechanical ventilation
* Infectious complications, such as pneumonia, sepsis, or catheter-related bloodstream infections
* Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to ruptured appendicitis or pancreatic mass
* Venous thromboembolism (VTE) or pulmonary embolism (PE) due to right subclavian vein thrombosis
* Electrolyte imbalances and potential for cardiac arrhythmias due to hypernatremia
* Anemia progression and potential for blood transfusions
* Fungal infections, such as candidemia or aspergillosis, due to prolonged hospitalization and antibiotic use

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continuing trials of pressure support ventilation (PSV) to wean off mechanical ventilation
* Weaning levophed as tolerated by mean arterial pressure (MAP) > 65
* Monitoring for signs of cardiac arrhythmias and potential for cardiac arrest
* Surveillance for infectious complications and potential for antibiotic-resistant infections
* Monitoring for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation
* Continuing anticoagulation therapy with heparin and warfarin to prevent VTE and PE
* Monitoring for signs of electrolyte imbalances and potential for cardiac arrhythmias
* Continuing anemia management and potential for blood transfusions
* Fungal surveillance and potential for antifungal therapy

The patient's disposition is ICU level of care, and the team will continue to monitor and manage the patient's complex medical conditions.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a diagnosis of sepsis without organ dysfunction, acute respiratory failure, and chronic renal failure. They are mechanically ventilated and receiving continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT). The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 106 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 98/53 mmHg. Their respiratory status is also stable, with a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 100%.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of acute kidney injury with non-oliguric renal failure, with a creatinine level of 1.9 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 38 mg/dL. Their electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with a potassium level of 4.1 mEq/L and a sodium level of 139 mg/dL.

The patient's physical examination is notable for marked swelling of all extremities, with right arm oozing transudative fluid. They are also intubated and sedated, with poor dentition and an endotracheal tube in place. Their neurological examination is abnormal, with the patient not following commands and not responding to painful stimuli.

The patient's medications include fentanyl, midazolam, amiodarone, norepinephrine, and heparin, among others. They are also receiving CRRT and have a PICC line, arterial line, and multi-lumen line in place.

Potential medical complications that may arise in this patient include:

1. Worsening of acute kidney injury and chronic renal failure, potentially leading to further electrolyte imbalances and fluid overload.
2. Development of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism due to prolonged immobility and presence of central lines.
3. Sepsis-induced cardiac dysfunction, potentially leading to cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac failure.
4. Respiratory failure, potentially requiring increased ventilatory support or consideration of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
5. Impaired skin integrity, potentially leading to pressure ulcers or skin breakdown.
6. Neurological complications, such as seizures or brain edema, due to sepsis-induced encephalopathy.
7. Gastrointestinal complications, such as stress ulcers or gastrointestinal bleeding, due to prolonged immobility and critical illness.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to address these potential complications and provide optimal care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-inch tall individual with a weight not specified, admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of sepsis without organ dysfunction, acute respiratory failure, chronic renal failure, atrial fibrillation, and impaired skin integrity.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.9°C (98.5°F)
* Heart rate: 106 bpm (102-130 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 98/53 mmHg (68-113/64 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 25 inspirations per minute (18-34 inspirations per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 100%

The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fractional inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%. The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) results are:

* pH: 7.28
* pCO2: 44 mmHg
* pO2: 91 mmHg
* HCO3: 19 mmol/L
* Base excess: -5 mmol/L

The patient has a history of chronic renal failure and is currently experiencing non-oliguric renal failure with acute tubular necrosis (ATN). The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and the patient is receiving furosemide (Lasix) to manage fluid overload.

The patient has a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the upper extremity and is receiving prophylactic anticoagulation therapy.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 8.8 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 8.0 g/dL
* Platelet count: 333 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.9 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 45 mg/dL
* Sodium: 139 mmol/L
* Potassium: 4.1 mmol/L
* Chloride: 119 mmol/L
* Carbon dioxide: 20 mmol/L
* Glucose: 144 mg/dL

The patient's medical history includes atrial fibrillation, and the patient is currently receiving anticoagulation therapy.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to the patient's intubation and mechanical ventilation. The patient's skin integrity is impaired, and the patient is at risk for further skin breakdown.

Based on the provided information, potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Further deterioration of the patient's respiratory status
* Development of acute kidney injury (AKI)
* Progression of the patient's chronic kidney disease (CKD)
* Increased risk of bleeding due to anticoagulation therapy
* Development of sepsis-related organ dysfunction
* Further skin breakdown and potential development of pressure ulcers
* Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism due to immobility and anticoagulation therapy.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and physical examination to identify any potential complications and adjust treatment accordingly.

   Assessment and Plan
   81 yo male with history of ruptured appendicitis and now with
   readmission with clinical picture consistent with sepsis and source
   remains to be defined.  This in addition has associated metabolic
   acidosis and peristent mild renal failure.  His recent picture has been
   one of failed capacity to tolerate wean in ventilatory support and wean
   of pressor support for hypotension.  This again, is all in the absence
   of significant cluture or radiographic evidence of focal source of
   infection.  His clinical picture is one of progressive decline in terms
   of respiratory status and no expectation to be able to successfully
   wean from ventilator.  His atrial fibrillation has been able to be
   better rate controlled and patient has failed cardioversion and
   amiodarone to trial to achieve sinus rhythm.  In addition he has
   persistent hypotension which has required increased pressor
   requirements.
   1)Respiratory Failure
he is limited by mental status and worsening
   secretions and inability to maintain effective ventilation
   -Patient to PSV to trial today
   -Continue Rx for possible pneumonia-_Vanco/Zosyn continued at D#4
   -Will continue to wean sedation as possible
   2)Atrial Fibrillation-
   -Amiodarone
   -ECHO today
   -Cardiology to evaluate patient for possible alternative approaches to
   stabilize rhythm
   3)DVT-
   Heparin to Coumadin
   4)Sepsis-
   -Foley changed following fungal culture in urine
   -Continue with broad spectrum ABX
   -Continue with levophed.
   -Re-culture for spike.
   5)Renal Failure-
   -Patient total body overloaded
   -Cr has shown minimal change but significantly impaired
   -Continue to look for opportunity for diuresis and will use leveophed
   to maintain BP
   -Would not offer dialysis at this time
   -Lasix gtt. And will start with bolus
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, sepsis, and atrial fibrillation. He has a history of ruptured appendicitis and readmission with clinical signs of sepsis and metabolic acidosis. The patient's condition has been declining, with failed wean attempts from ventilator and pressor support. He has persistent hypotension, atrial fibrillation, and renal failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status continues to deteriorate, making it unlikely for him to successfully wean from the ventilator.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is ongoing, with a broad-spectrum antibiotic regimen in place. There is a risk of further organ dysfunction and mortality.
3. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is persistent, and he has failed cardioversion and amiodarone trials to achieve sinus rhythm. This increases the risk of stroke, heart failure, and arrhythmia.
4. DVT: The patient is at risk for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to his immobility and the use of heparin.
5. Renal Failure: The patient's renal function is impaired, and he has persistent hypotension, which may exacerbate his renal failure.
6. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis is ongoing, which can lead to further organ dysfunction and mortality.
7. Infection: The patient has a high risk of developing further infections due to his immunocompromised state and the presence of invasive devices.

Recommendations:

1. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy for sepsis.
2. Wean sedation as possible to improve respiratory status.
3. Consider alternative approaches to stabilize the patient's atrial fibrillation.
4. Monitor for DVT and consider prophylactic measures.
5. Continue to manage the patient's renal failure with diuretics and vasopressors.
6. Consider consults with Cardiology and Nephrology to optimize management.
7. Consult the Ethics team to aid in setting goals of care in the absence of clear patient wishes.

ICU Care:

1. Nutrition: Continue with Nutren Renal (Full) and regular insulin sliding scale for glycemic control.
2. Lines: Monitor PICC, arterial, and multi-lumen lines for patency and potential complications.
3. Prophylaxis: Continue DVT prophylaxis with heparin and stress ulcer prophylaxis with PPI.
4. VAP: Monitor for ventilator-associated pneumonia and consider antibiotic therapy if necessary.
5. Communication: Consult with the Ethics team to aid in setting goals of care in the absence of clear patient wishes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the ICU with a complex medical condition. The patient's chief complaint is likely related to acute respiratory failure, and the note suggests that the patient may have developed a deep venous thrombosis (DVT) in the upper extremity.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C (97.8°F), heart rate of 119 bpm, and blood pressure of 116/62 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is compromised, with a respiratory rate of 34 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 96% on 40% fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2).

The patient's laboratory results indicate acute kidney injury, with a creatinine level of 1.9 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 23 mmol/L. The patient's liver function tests are mildly elevated, with an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 46 IU/L and an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 26 IU/L.

The patient is receiving multiple medications, including anticoagulants, antibiotics, and vasopressors. The patient is also receiving nutrition through a nasogastric tube and has a central venous catheter (CVC) in place.

The patient's medical history is significant for chronic kidney disease, atrial fibrillation, and respiratory failure. The patient's family history is significant for a history of cardiovascular disease.

Based on the patient's condition, potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
2. Sepsis and septic shock
3. Deep venous thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE)
4. Acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease progression
5. Respiratory failure and need for mechanical ventilation
6. Cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac arrest
7. Infection and sepsis
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation
9. Skin breakdown and pressure ulcers
10. Nutritional deficiencies and electrolyte imbalances.

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix, who was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR). He was intubated for respiratory failure and has been receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient has a complex medical condition with multiple comorbidities, including chronic kidney disease, anemia, and pancreatitis. He has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and vasopressors.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is mechanically ventilated and is requiring a high level of support. He has a respiratory rate of 34 breaths per minute and a tidal volume of 500 mL.
* Hemodynamics: The patient has atrial fibrillation with RVR, which is likely due to septic shock. He has a mixed venous oxygen saturation of 29.8% and a central venous pressure of 24 mmHg.
* Fever: The patient has a temperature of 36.6°C (97.8°F) and is receiving antipyretic therapy.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is elevated at 135 mg/dL, which is likely due to the administration of hypertonic fluids.
* Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is 10.1 g/dL, which is low for his age and medical condition.
* Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient has a thrombosis in his right subclavian vein, which is likely due to the insertion of a central venous catheter.
* Ruptured appendicitis: The patient has a history of ruptured appendicitis, which was medically managed.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to a combination of factors, including his underlying lung disease, septic shock, and the administration of sedatives and paralytics.
* Sepsis: The patient has a high suspicion of sepsis, which could lead to further complications, including organ failure and death.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation with RVR could lead to further cardiac complications, including heart failure and arrhythmias.
* Renal failure: The patient's chronic kidney disease and acute kidney injury could lead to further renal failure and the need for dialysis.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia could lead to further complications, including fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased tolerance to therapy.
* Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient's thrombosis could lead to further complications, including pulmonary embolism and deep vein thrombosis.
* Ruptured appendicitis: The patient's ruptured appendicitis could lead to further complications, including abscess formation and peritonitis.

Recommendations:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as needed.
* Consider transferring the patient to a cardiac intensive care unit (ICU) for further management of his cardiac condition.
* Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamics and adjust his vasopressor therapy as needed.
* Consider adding antibiotics to the patient's regimen to treat potential sepsis.
* Continue to monitor the patient's sodium level and adjust his fluid therapy as needed.
* Consider adding a diuretic to the patient's regimen to treat his anemia.
* Continue to monitor the patient's right subclavian vein thrombosis and consider adding anticoagulant therapy as needed.
* Consider adding an antibiotic to the patient's regimen to treat potential appendicitis.

   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). Was not extubated yesterday
   due to pH 7.19 after one hour on PS.
   - Continue trials of PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Try RSBI
   and SBT
   - Issues that could complicate extubation: mental status (very sedated)
   and minute volume requirement required to compensate for metabolic
   acidosis.
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Cardiology was consulted last night;
   recommended digoxin loading.
   - Continue chemical cardioversion with amio, digoxin (dose by level
   given ARF)
   - Wean levophed as tolerated by MAP > 65
   - f/u cardiology recs
   - repeat  echo pending
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. other occult infectious
   process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC count and
   has been afebrile x 48 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a robust
   inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically ill
   state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. There is a concern for
   fungal infection given pt
s prolonged abx course and frequent hospital
   stays. Yeast in urine and sputum. MRSA screen pos.
   - C. diff negative [**4-25**]
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn started [**4-23**] given initial decompensation. (Day 4
   today)
   - Surveillance blood cultures - NGTD
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   - ID denied empiric fluconazole; will f/u glucan and galactomannin and
   re-assess once data available.
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis. Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.  Has
   received Bicarb. Likely to improve with diuresis.
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: was resolving, however borderline high again in the
   setting of restarting tube feeds.
   - increase free water boluses to 250 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure:  Cr stable at 1.8
 2.0. Patient now

   - F/u nephrology recs

   .

   stable x 3+ days.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional (LOS 15.5L positive).
   He was noted to be anemic with guaiac positive stools during last

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR). He has been intubated for respiratory failure and has a history of ruptured appendix, medically managed. The patient has been receiving antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy, and has been diagnosed with right subclavian vein thrombosis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: intubated for respiratory failure, with a respiratory rate of 34 breaths per minute and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.
* Cardiovascular: atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, with a heart rate of 119 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 116/62 mmHg.
* Hemodynamic: mixed venous oxygen saturation (SvO2) of 29.8%, indicating distributive shock.
* Renal: acute on chronic renal failure, with a creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL and a urine output of 4,335 mL over the past 24 hours.
* Electrolytes: hypernatremia, with a sodium level of 135 mg/dL and a potassium level of 4.1 mEq/L.
* Infectious disease: suspected fungal infection, with yeast in the urine and sputum, and a positive MRSA screen.
* Gastrointestinal: diarrhea, with a guaiac-positive stool.
* Hematological: anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 10.1 g/dL.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: continued respiratory failure, with a high risk of reintubation.
* Cardiovascular: continued atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, with a high risk of cardiac arrest.
* Hemodynamic: continued distributive shock, with a high risk of organ failure.
* Renal: continued acute on chronic renal failure, with a high risk of worsening renal function.
* Infectious disease: continued suspected fungal infection, with a high risk of sepsis and organ failure.
* Gastrointestinal: continued diarrhea, with a high risk of dehydration and electrolyte imbalance.
* Hematological: continued anemia, with a high risk of bleeding and organ failure.

Assessment and plan:

The patient's condition is complex and requires ongoing monitoring and management. The patient's respiratory failure, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and distributive shock require continued mechanical ventilation, anticoagulation therapy, and vasopressor support. The patient's acute on chronic renal failure requires ongoing fluid management and electrolyte replacement. The patient's suspected fungal infection requires ongoing antifungal therapy and monitoring for signs of sepsis. The patient's diarrhea requires ongoing fluid and electrolyte replacement. The patient's anemia requires ongoing blood transfusions and monitoring for signs of bleeding.

The patient's overall prognosis is poor, and the healthcare team is considering an ethics consultation to discuss end-of-life care and palliation. The patient's code status is full code, and the healthcare team is recommending continued ICU-level care to manage the patient's complex medical condition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with a complex medical condition. The patient has been admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of sepsis, acute respiratory failure, and chronic renal failure. The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a respiratory rate of 34 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 96%.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 119 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 116/62 mmHg. The patient's cardiac rhythm is atrial fibrillation, and they have a central venous catheter and an arterial line in place.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate level, and troponin level, consistent with sepsis. The patient's creatinine level is elevated, indicating chronic renal failure. The patient's electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypernatremia.

The patient's medication list includes antibiotics, vasopressors, and sedatives. The patient has received two units of packed red blood cells, and their fluid balance is positive.

The patient's physical examination shows signs of sepsis, including tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension. The patient's skin is warm, and they have marked swelling in their extremities.

Based on the patient's condition, potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is high, and they are mechanically ventilated. There is a risk of respiratory failure and the need for further respiratory support.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac rhythm is atrial fibrillation, and there is a risk of cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
3. Sepsis: The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count and lactate level, consistent with sepsis. There is a risk of further deterioration and the need for additional antibiotics and supportive care.
4. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, indicating chronic renal failure. There is a risk of further deterioration and the need for dialysis.
5. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, with hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypernatremia. There is a risk of further deterioration and the need for electrolyte replacement therapy.
6. Skin integrity: The patient's skin is warm, and they have marked swelling in their extremities. There is a risk of skin breakdown and the need for further skin care and wound management.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

   81 yo male with ruptured appendicitis now with prolonged respiratory
   failure and hypotension with multiple contributing factors including
   sepsis, atrial-fibrillation, possible right heart compromise and
   intra-vascular depletion.  He, thanks to cardiology input, has had
   transfusion of 2 units PRBC and been able to have some significant
   weaning of pressors this morning
   1)Respiratory Failure-
   -Lasix gtt
   -PSV to wean down as tolerated
   -CXR without signficiant change
   -Secretions are limited
   -Continue with vanco/zosyn
10 day course
   -Start Fluconazole given clinical picture and B-glucan findings
   2)Atrial Fibrillation
   -Amiodarone
   -Coumadin
   -Digoxin
will need to clarify goals of the Digoxin
   -TEE and cardioversion if cardiology would feel we have a reasonable
   chance of success
urgency will depend on capacity to maintain pressors
   off.
   3)Altered Mental Status-
   -Will wean sedation as possible today
   -Likely multifactorial
   -Patient with increased alertness this morning which is encoura
   4)Acute Renal Failure-
   -Bicarb with substantial improvement with support of renal function
   5)Hematuria-
   -Will need follow up evaluation and if clots worsening with obstruction
   will move to 3-way foley

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

Patient's Condition:

* Respiratory failure with prolonged mechanical ventilation
* Septic shock with hypotension and multi-organ dysfunction
* Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular rate
* Possible right heart compromise and intravascular depletion
* Acute renal failure with oliguria and electrolyte imbalance
* Hematuria with potential for clot formation and obstruction
* Altered mental status with increased sedation requirements
* Prolonged ICU stay with multiple comorbidities

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged mechanical ventilation
2. Sepsis-induced acute kidney injury (AKI) and worsening renal function
3. Right heart failure and cardiac arrhythmias due to sepsis and atrial fibrillation
4. Intra-abdominal hypertension and abdominal compartment syndrome due to prolonged mechanical ventilation and fluid overload
5. Pressure ulcers and skin breakdown due to prolonged immobility and poor nutrition
6. Malnutrition and electrolyte imbalance due to prolonged ICU stay and inadequate nutrition
7. Worsening mental status and delirium due to prolonged sedation and multi-organ dysfunction
8. Increased risk of bleeding and clot formation due to prolonged anticoagulation therapy and hematuria
9. Potential for further cardiac complications, such as cardiac tamponade or ventricular dysfunction, due to sepsis and atrial fibrillation.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient requires continued close monitoring and management of his multiple comorbidities. The plan includes:

1. Weaning of pressors and mechanical ventilation as tolerated
2. Continued antibiotic therapy for sepsis and pneumonia
3. Management of atrial fibrillation with antiarrhythmic medications and cardioversion
4. Monitoring and management of acute renal failure and electrolyte imbalance
5. Nutritional support with enteral nutrition and glycemic control
6. Prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia
7. Regular assessment and management of mental status and delirium
8. Monitoring for signs of worsening cardiac function and right heart failure.

The patient requires continued close monitoring and management in the ICU to prevent and treat potential complications and to optimize his outcome.
