   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). More alert and tolerating PS
   15/5 better this AM than previously.
   - Continue trials of PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Repeat
   RSBI
   - Issues that could complicate extubation: mental status (gets agitated
   when awake and overbreathes the vent to RR of 40) and minute volume
   requirement required to compensate for metabolic acidosis.
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Was transfused 2 u pRBCs last night per
   Cardiology who felt pt was intravascularly volume depleted, and HR came
   down from 110s-130s to 90-100s. Echo highly suspicious for PE, however
   pt already systemically anticoagulated and renal failure precludes CTA
   chest.
   - Appreciate cardiology recs. Discuss switching to PO amio and d/c
   digoxin
   - Wean levophed as tolerated.
   - Continue lasix (started yesterday [**4-26**]) with goal 1L negative today
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. other occult infectious
   process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC count and
   has been afebrile x 48 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a robust
   inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically ill
   state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. B-glucan floridly
   positive (>500) which is not surprising given pt
s prolonged abx
   courses, frequent hospital stays and h/o TPN. Yeast in urine and
   sputum. MRSA screen pos.
   - C. diff negative [**4-25**]
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn started [**4-22**] given initial decompensation. (Day 6
   today)
   - Start fluconazole today for fungemia
   - Surveillance blood cultures - NGTD
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis. Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.  Has
   received Bicarb. Likely to improve with diuresis.
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: was resolving, however borderline high again in the
   setting of restarting tube feeds.
   - increase free water boluses to 250 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure:  Cr stable at 1.8
 2.0. Patient now
   adequately fluid resuscitated. FENa 1.26%, so likely not entirely
   pre-renal.
   - monitor closely as lasix is being given
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Currently in the high20s,
   stable x 3+ days.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional (LOS 15L positive).  He
   was noted to be anemic with guaiac positive stools during last
   admission.  B12,  folate, & iron  within normal limits (though ferritin
   may be elevated as an acute phase reactant and should be rechecked).
   [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT. INR therapeutic at 2.2.
   - Cont warfarin
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone and fluconazole
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  Rec'd one dose of
   vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  CT abdomen showing
   no drainable fluid collection
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn Day [**7-17**] (started [**4-22**]) for broad spectrum
   coverage in the absence of specific microbio data; also adding
   fluconazole today
   - [**Doctor First Name 3**] recs: OK to feed; TF started [**4-24**]
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, TF with incr free water flushes
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with warfarin, lansoprazole,
   bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from last admission), A-line, R fem CVC [**4-23**]
   (consider pulling PICC when possible given possible fungemia)
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, HCP [**Name (NI) 4955**] [**Name (NI) 4961**] (neighbor; number in
   chart)
   .

   Differential-Neuts:76.6 %, Lymph:15.7 %, Mono:6.0 %, Eos:1.1 %, Lactic

   Mg++:1.9 mg/dL, PO4:3.1 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). More alert and tolerating PS
   15/5 better this AM than previously.
   - Continue trials of PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Repeat
   RSBI
   - Issues that could complicate extubation: mental status (gets agitated
   when awake and overbreathes the vent to RR of 40) and minute volume
   requirement required to compensate for metabolic acidosis.
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Was transfused 2 u pRBCs last night per
   Cardiology who felt pt was intravascularly volume depleted, and HR came
   down from 110s-130s to 90-100s. Echo highly suspicious for PE, however
   pt already systemically anticoagulated and renal failure precludes CTA
   chest.
   - Appreciate cardiology recs. Discuss switching to PO amio and d/c
   digoxin
   - Wean levophed as tolerated.
   - Continue lasix (started yesterday [**4-26**]) with goal 1L negative today
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. other occult infectious
   process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC count and
   has been afebrile x 48 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a robust
   inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically ill
   state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. B-glucan floridly
   positive (>500) which is not surprising given pt
s prolonged abx
   courses, frequent hospital stays and h/o TPN. Yeast in urine and
   sputum. MRSA screen pos.
   - C. diff negative [**4-25**]
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn started [**4-22**] given initial decompensation. (Day 6
   today)
   - Start fluconazole today for fungemia
   - Surveillance blood cultures - NGTD
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis. Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.  Has
   received Bicarb. Likely to improve with diuresis.
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: was resolving, however borderline high again in the
   setting of restarting tube feeds.
   - increase free water boluses to 250 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure:  Cr stable at 1.8
 2.0. Patient now
   adequately fluid resuscitated. FENa 1.26%, so likely not entirely
   pre-renal.
   - monitor closely as lasix is being given
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Currently in the high20s,
   stable x 3+ days.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional (LOS 15L positive).  He
   was noted to be anemic with guaiac positive stools during last
   admission.  B12,  folate, & iron  within normal limits (though ferritin
   may be elevated as an acute phase reactant and should be rechecked).
   [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT. INR therapeutic at 2.2.
   - Cont warfarin
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone and fluconazole
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  Rec'd one dose of
   vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  CT abdomen showing
   no drainable fluid collection
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn Day [**7-17**] (started [**4-22**]) for broad spectrum
   coverage in the absence of specific microbio data; also adding
   fluconazole today
   - [**Doctor First Name 3**] recs: OK to feed; TF started [**4-24**]
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, TF with incr free water flushes
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with warfarin, lansoprazole,
   bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from last admission), A-line, R fem CVC [**4-23**]
   (consider pulling PICC when possible given possible fungemia)
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, HCP [**Name (NI) 4955**] [**Name (NI) 4961**] (neighbor; number in
   chart)
   .
   # Disposition: requires ICU level of care while intubated
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, atrial fibrillation, and chronic heart failure, who was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. He was intubated for respiratory failure and has been on mechanical ventilation since admission. His current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.1°C (98.8°F)
* Heart rate: 101 bpm
* Blood pressure: 109/55 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 97%
* Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response

The patient has been experiencing fever, which may be related to worsening of his ruptured appendicitis, aspiration pneumonitis from intubation, or occult infectious process. He has been treated with antibiotics, including ciprofloxacin and flagyl, and has been started on fluconazole for fungemia.

The patient has also been experiencing hypernatremia, which has been resolving, but has increased again with the restarting of tube feeds. His electrolyte levels are:

* Sodium: 147 mmol/L
* Potassium: 4.3 mmol/L
* Chloride: 102 mmol/L
* Bicarbonate: 22 mmol/L

The patient has been experiencing anemia, which may be related to chronic kidney disease, and has been treated with blood transfusions.

The patient has also been experiencing right subclavian vein thrombosis, which has been treated with warfarin, and has been experiencing a ruptured appendicitis, which has been medically managed.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is at risk for further respiratory failure.
2. Septic shock: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest that he may be at risk for septic shock.
3. Fungemia: The patient's positive fungal cultures and fungemia may lead to further complications, such as sepsis or disseminated fungal infection.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may lead to further complications, such as seizures, coma, or death.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may lead to further complications, such as decreased oxygen delivery to tissues or decreased cardiac output.
6. Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient's right subclavian vein thrombosis may lead to further complications, such as pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis.
7. Ruptured appendicitis: The patient's ruptured appendicitis may lead to further complications, such as peritonitis or abscess formation.

Assessment and plan:

The patient's condition is unstable, and he requires close monitoring and treatment to prevent further complications. The patient's respiratory status should be closely monitored, and he should be weaned off mechanical ventilation as soon as possible. The patient's fever should be treated with antibiotics, and he should be started on antifungal therapy to prevent fungemia. The patient's hypernatremia should be treated with free water boluses, and his anemia should be treated with blood transfusions. The patient's right subclavian vein thrombosis should be treated with warfarin, and his ruptured appendicitis should be treated with antibiotics and close monitoring.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following information can be summarized:

* The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU patient with a complex medical history, including chronic renal failure, atrial fibrillation, and sepsis without organ dysfunction.
* The patient's current condition is stable, with vital signs within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated heart rate and blood pressure.
* The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute.
* The patient is receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, antifungals, and vasopressors, as well as fluids and electrolyte replacement.
* The patient's laboratory results show evidence of acidosis, hypernatremia, and chronic renal failure.
* The patient has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and is at risk for further thrombotic complications.
* The patient's skin integrity is impaired, with evidence of edema and potential pressure ulcers.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Further deterioration of the patient's respiratory status, potentially leading to respiratory failure.
* Development of septic shock or cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
* Progression of the patient's chronic renal failure, potentially leading to acute kidney injury or end-stage renal disease.
* Thrombotic complications, such as pulmonary embolism or further DVT.
* Development of pressure ulcers or other skin complications.
* Infections, such as central line-associated bloodstream infections or ventilator-associated pneumonia.
* Gastrointestinal complications, such as stress ulceration or gastrointestinal bleeding.

Based on this information, the patient's care plan should focus on optimizing their respiratory and cardiovascular status, managing their fluid and electrolyte balance, and preventing further complications. Close monitoring and frequent reassessment are necessary to ensure the patient's safety and to make any necessary adjustments to their care plan.

Summary:

The patient is a 66-year-old individual admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of sepsis, acute respiratory failure, and chronic renal failure. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 101 beats per minute, blood pressure of 109/55 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a peak inspiratory pressure of 24 cmH2O and a fraction of inspired oxygen of 40%. The patient's respiratory support is being weaned, and the ventilator mode has been changed to CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow.

The patient has been receiving various medications, including fluconazole for a positive beta-glucan, warfarin, and norepinephrine. The patient's blood products have been transfused, and the patient's platelet count has been monitored.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of acidosis, hypernatremia, and chronic renal failure. The patient's troponin-T level is elevated, and the patient's lactate acid level is 1.1 mmol/L.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory support is being weaned, and the patient's respiratory status is still unstable. The patient is at risk for developing respiratory failure if the ventilator is discontinued or if the patient's respiratory muscles are unable to sustain spontaneous ventilation.
2. Renal failure: The patient has chronic renal failure, and the patient's creatinine level is 1.8 mg/dL. The patient is at risk for developing acute renal failure if the patient's blood pressure is not controlled or if the patient's fluid status is not optimized.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient has atrial fibrillation, and the patient's troponin-T level is elevated. The patient is at risk for developing cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock, if the patient's cardiac function is not optimized.
4. Infection: The patient has sepsis, and the patient's white blood cell count is 7.3. The patient is at risk for developing a secondary infection if the patient's immune system is not functioning properly.
5. Skin integrity: The patient has impaired skin integrity, and the patient is at risk for developing pressure ulcers or skin breakdown if the patient's skin is not properly cared for.
6. DVT: The patient has a deep venous thrombosis in the upper extremity, and the patient is at risk for developing a pulmonary embolism if the patient's DVT is not properly treated.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications. The patient's respiratory, renal, and cardiac status require close monitoring and optimization. The patient's infection and skin integrity require proper management to prevent secondary complications. The patient's DVT requires proper treatment to prevent pulmonary embolism.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). Tolerating PS 12/5 well this
   morning, but NIF only -11.
   - Continue PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Repeat RSBI/NIF
   daily-[**Hospital1 **].
   -
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Was transfused 2 u pRBCs last night per
   Cardiology who felt pt was intravascularly volume depleted, and HR came
   down from 110s-130s to 90-100s. Echo highly suspicious for PE, however
   pt already systemically anticoagulated and renal failure precludes CTA
   chest.
   - Appreciate cardiology recs. Discuss switching to PO amio and d/c
   digoxin
   - Wean levophed as tolerated.
   - Continue lasix (started yesterday [**4-26**]) with goal 1L negative today
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. other occult infectious
   process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC count and
   has been afebrile x 48 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a robust
   inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically ill
   state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. B-glucan floridly
   positive (>500) which is not surprising given pt
s prolonged abx
   courses, frequent hospital stays and h/o TPN. Yeast in urine and
   sputum. MRSA screen pos.
   - C. diff negative [**4-25**]
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn started [**4-22**] given initial decompensation. (Day 6
   today)
   - Start fluconazole today for fungemia
   - Surveillance blood cultures - NGTD
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis. Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.  Has
   received Bicarb. Likely to improve with diuresis.
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: was resolving, however borderline high again in the
   setting of restarting tube feeds.
   - increase free water boluses to 250 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure:  Cr stable at 1.8
 2.0. Patient now
   adequately fluid resuscitated. FENa 1.26%, so likely not entirely
   pre-renal.
   - monitor closely as lasix is being given
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Currently in the high20s,
   stable x 3+ days.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional (LOS 15L positive).  He
   was noted to be anemic with guaiac positive stools during last
   admission.  B12,  folate, & iron  within normal limits (though ferritin
   may be elevated as an acute phase reactant and should be rechecked).
   [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT. INR therapeutic at 2.2.
   - Cont warfarin
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone and fluconazole
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  Rec'd one dose of
   vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  CT abdomen showing
   no drainable fluid collection
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn Day [**7-17**] (started [**4-22**]) for broad spectrum
   coverage in the absence of specific microbio data; also adding
   fluconazole today
   - [**Doctor First Name 3**] recs: OK to feed; TF started [**4-24**]
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, TF with incr free water flushes
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with warfarin, lansoprazole,
   bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from last admission), A-line, R fem CVC [**4-23**]
   (consider pulling PICC when possible given possible fungemia)
   .

   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate

   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). Tolerating PS 12/5 well this
   morning, but NIF only -11.
   - Continue PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Repeat RSBI/NIF
   daily-[**Hospital1 **].
   -
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Was transfused 2 u pRBCs last night per
   Cardiology who felt pt was intravascularly volume depleted, and HR came
   down from 110s-130s to 90-100s. Echo highly suspicious for PE, however
   pt already systemically anticoagulated and renal failure precludes CTA
   chest.
   - Appreciate cardiology recs. Discuss switching to PO amio and d/c
   digoxin
   - Wean levophed as tolerated.
   - Continue lasix (started yesterday [**4-26**]) with goal 1L negative today
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. other occult infectious
   process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC count and
   has been afebrile x 48 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a robust
   inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically ill
   state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. B-glucan floridly
   positive (>500) which is not surprising given pt
s prolonged abx
   courses, frequent hospital stays and h/o TPN. Yeast in urine and
   sputum. MRSA screen pos.
   - C. diff negative [**4-25**]
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn started [**4-22**] given initial decompensation. (Day 6
   today)
   - Start fluconazole today for fungemia
   - Surveillance blood cultures - NGTD
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis. Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.  Has
   received Bicarb. Likely to improve with diuresis.
   - Continue to trend
   .

   - monitor

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with RVR, and was intubated for respiratory failure.

Current vital signs:

* Temperature: 37.1°C
* Heart rate: 101 bpm
* Blood pressure: 109/55 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 97%

The patient has been on various medications, including fluconazole for fungal infections, warfarin for anticoagulation, and lasix for diuresis. He has also been receiving nutritional support through a feeding tube.

Lab results:

* White blood cell count: 7.3-8.5 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.6-10.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 309-330 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.8-2.0 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 27-29 mEq/L
* Sodium: 144-147 mmol/L
* Potassium: 3.6-3.7 mmol/L
* Chloride: 113-115 mmol/L
* Calcium: 7.2-7.5 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9-2.1 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.1-3.3 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.1 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.2 g/dL
* LDH: 238 IU/L

The patient has several medical complications, including:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.
* Atrial fibrillation with RVR: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation with RVR, and is currently anticoagulated with warfarin.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is elevated, and he is receiving free water boluses to correct this.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he is receiving lasix for diuresis.
* Fungal infections: The patient has a positive fungal culture, and is receiving fluconazole for treatment.
* Ruptured appendix: The patient has a history of ruptured appendix, and is receiving antibiotics for prophylaxis.

Potential medical complications that could arise include:

* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation with RVR could worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure could worsen, leading to further decline in oxygenation.
* Sepsis: The patient's fungal infections could lead to sepsis, which could worsen his overall condition.
* Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury could worsen, leading to further decline in kidney function.
* Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's electrolyte imbalances could worsen, leading to further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a complex medical history, including lung cancer, prostate cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation, and chronic kidney disease (CKD). He is currently intubated in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to respiratory failure.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1°C (98.8°F), heart rate of 101 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 109/55 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 97% on a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of metabolic acidosis, with a pH of 7.44 and a base excess of -1.8 mmol/L. His bicarbonate level is 22 mmol/L, and his anion gap is 12 mmol/L. His creatinine level is 1.8 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 27 mg/dL.

The patient's chest radiograph shows a left pleural effusion, and his electrocardiogram (ECG) shows atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. His echocardiogram shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 30%, and his cardiac index is 2.2 L/min/m².

The patient's abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan shows a ruptured appendix, and his stool culture is positive for Candida. His urine culture is also positive for Candida, and his blood culture is pending.

The patient's medication list includes amiodarone, warfarin, fluconazole, and levophed. His IV fluids include normal saline, D5W, and lactated Ringer's solution.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require ongoing mechanical ventilation.
2. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may require ongoing treatment with bicarbonate and other medications.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and rapid ventricular response may require ongoing treatment with medications such as amiodarone and warfarin.
4. Renal failure: The patient's chronic kidney disease may worsen due to ongoing fluid resuscitation and the use of nephrotoxic medications.
5. Candidemia: The patient's positive blood culture for Candida may require ongoing treatment with antifungal medications such as fluconazole.
6. Sepsis: The patient's positive blood culture for Candida and his underlying medical conditions may increase his risk of developing sepsis.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of ruptured appendix and his ongoing treatment with antibiotics may increase his risk of developing gastrointestinal complications such as Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) colitis.
8. Venous thromboembolism (VTE): The patient's history of right subclavian vein thrombosis and his ongoing treatment with warfarin may increase his risk of developing VTE.

In summary, the patient is a complex medical case with multiple potential complications. He requires ongoing monitoring and treatment to manage his respiratory failure, metabolic acidosis, cardiac complications, and other medical conditions.

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix, who was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with RVR. He was intubated for respiratory failure and has been on mechanical ventilation since admission. The patient has a complex medical condition with multiple comorbidities, including chronic kidney disease, anemia, and suspected fungemia.

Current Status:

* Respiratory status: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. He has a rapid shallow breathing index (RSBI) of 77, indicating that he may not be weaning well from the ventilator.
* Hemodynamic status: The patient has atrial fibrillation with RVR, which is likely due to a septic state. He has received fluid resuscitation and is being monitored closely for signs of distributive shock.
* Metabolic status: The patient has a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, which is likely due to saline resuscitation, diarrhea, or renal failure. He has received bicarbonate therapy and is being monitored closely.
* Renal status: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, with a creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL. He is receiving lasix therapy and is being monitored closely for signs of worsening renal function.
* Anemia: The patient has a baseline anemia level of around 37, which is stable. He is being monitored closely for signs of worsening anemia.
* Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient has a significant erythema and edema of the right upper extremity, which is being treated with warfarin therapy.

Potential Medical Complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient may not be weaning well from the ventilator, which could lead to respiratory failure.
* Sepsis: The patient has a suspected septic state, which could lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
* Renal failure: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, which could worsen with continued lasix therapy.
* Fungemia: The patient has a suspected fungemia, which could lead to septicemia and organ dysfunction.
* Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient has a significant erythema and edema of the right upper extremity, which could lead to complications such as embolism or gangrene.
* Pancreatic mass: The patient has a pancreatic mass, which could lead to complications such as pancreatitis or pancreatic duct obstruction.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient requires continued close monitoring and management of his complex medical condition. The plan is to continue trials of pressure support ventilation to wean him off the ventilator, monitor his hemodynamic status closely, and adjust his fluid resuscitation and diuretic therapy as needed. The patient will also require continued antibiotic therapy for suspected fungemia and sepsis, as well as close monitoring of his renal function and electrolyte levels.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR), and was intubated for respiratory failure.

The patient has been experiencing various complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is still intubated and requires mechanical ventilation. The plan is to continue PSV in anticipation of weaning off the ventilator.
2. Hemodynamics: The patient has atrial fibrillation with RVR, which is likely due to a septic state. He has a history of atrial fibrillation with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past.
3. Abdominal pain: The patient has a history of medically managed ruptured appendicitis, and his abdominal pain is difficult to assess due to his altered mental status. He is stooling well, but has no residuals with tube feeding.
4. Fever: The patient had been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a ruptured appendicitis, and his fever may represent worsening of this process or an occult infectious process.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia is resolving, but is still borderline high in the setting of restarting tube feeds.
6. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's creatinine is stable at 1.8, and he is adequately fluid resuscitated.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia is stable, and he is being monitored for further changes.
8. Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient has significant erythema and edema of his right upper extremity, and is being treated with warfarin.
9. Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: The patient has been on Cipro/flagyl since last admission, and has been afebrile and without leukocytosis.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient may experience further respiratory failure if his respiratory status does not improve.
2. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's atrial fibrillation with RVR may lead to further hemodynamic instability.
3. Abdominal sepsis: The patient's abdominal pain and fever may indicate the development of abdominal sepsis.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure may worsen if his kidney function does not improve.
5. Bleeding: The patient's anticoagulation therapy may increase his risk of bleeding.
6. Infection: The patient's prolonged hospital stay and multiple antibiotic courses may increase his risk of developing an infection.

Based on the patient's condition, the following plan is recommended:

1. Continue PSV in anticipation of weaning off the ventilator.
2. Monitor the patient's hemodynamics and adjust his anticoagulation therapy as needed.
3. Continue to manage the patient's abdominal pain and fever.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his fluid management as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's anemia and adjust his transfusion therapy as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's right subclavian vein thrombosis and adjust his anticoagulation therapy as needed.
7. Consider consulting a gastrointestinal specialist to further evaluate the patient's abdominal pain and to discuss the possibility of a tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's infection risk and adjust his antibiotic therapy as needed.
9. Consider consulting a nephrologist to further evaluate the patient's acute on chronic renal failure and to discuss the possibility of dialysis.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-inch tall individual with a history of chronic renal failure, atrial fibrillation, and sepsis without organ dysfunction. The patient is currently in the ICU for respiratory failure, acute, and has been receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.9°C (100.3°F) with a current temperature of 37.1°C (98.7°F)
* Heart rate: 96 beats per minute with a range of 89-110 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 94/45 mmHg with a range of 61-130/68-90 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 24 breaths per minute with a range of 15-40 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 96%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 7.4 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 10.0 g/dL
* Platelet count: 309 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.9 mg/dL
* Glucose: 137 mg/dL
* Potassium: 4.0 mEq/L
* Sodium: 137 mg/dL
* Chloride: 25 mEq/L
* Bicarbonate: 28.9 mmol/L

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Acidosis, metabolic
* Deep venous thrombosis, upper extremity
* Sepsis without organ dysfunction
* Fever (hypothermia, pyrexia, not fever of unknown origin)
* Hypernatremia (high sodium)
* Renal failure, chronic
* Atrial fibrillation
* Respiratory failure, acute
* Impaired skin integrity

The patient's plan includes:

* Continued mechanical ventilation
* Norepinephrine infusion
* Fentanyl infusion
* Midazolam infusion
* Antibiotics: vancomycin, fluconazole, and piperacillin
* Nutrition: Nutren Renal (Full) at 35 mL/hour
* Glycemic control
* Prophylaxis: DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Respiratory failure: worsening hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and respiratory acidosis
* Sepsis: progression to septic shock, organ dysfunction, and mortality
* Deep venous thrombosis: pulmonary embolism, leg pain, and swelling
* Renal failure: worsening azotemia, electrolyte imbalance, and acidosis
* Atrial fibrillation: stroke, heart failure, and mortality
* Hypernatremia: seizures, neurological deficits, and mortality
* Impaired skin integrity: pressure ulcers, infection, and sepsis

Based on the patient's condition, it is essential to continue monitoring their vital signs, laboratory results, and medical conditions closely to prevent and manage potential complications.

   Assessment and PlanThis is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p
   resection, prostate ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD,
   SVT, CHF and ruptured appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with
   hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for
   respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). Tolerating PS 12/5 well this
   morning, but NIF only -11.
   - Continue PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Repeat RSBI/NIF
   daily-[**Hospital1 **].
   - Barriers to extubation: anxiety level, poor NIF (weakness).
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Was transfused 2 u pRBCs 3/24 per
   Cardiology who felt pt was intravascularly volume depleted, and HR came
   down from 110s-130s to 90-100s. Echo highly suspicious for PE, however
   pt already systemically anticoagulated and renal failure precludes CTA
   chest.
   - Appreciate cardiology recs. d/c
d digoxin yesterday and amio
   converted from gtt to po yesterday.
   - Wean levophed as tolerated
   - minimize sedation as pt becomes hypotensive easily
   - d/c
d lasix yesterday around midnight due to hypotension; continues
   to make good urine although lasix was discontinued; Will not restart
   lasix for now
   .
   # Abdominal pain: difficult to assess as pt
s sensorium is not
   completely clear, however it
s worrisome given his history of medically
   managed ruptured appendicitis. Pt is stooling well (1-3 times a day),
   C.diff neg x 1, and has no residuals with TF.
   - Hold TF for now
   - Check KUB for ileus or obstruction
   - Consider CT abd/pelvis if KUB negative and exam becomes more
   worrisome
   - check LFTs, [**Doctor First Name **], lipase
   - Consider [**Doctor First Name **] consult
   - recheck C. diff
   # Fever: Patient had been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. other occult infectious
   process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC count and
   has been afebrile x 72+ hours. Pt may not be able to mount a robust
   inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically ill
   state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. B-glucan floridly
   positive (>500) which is not surprising given pt
s prolonged abx
   courses, frequent hospital stays and h/o TPN. Yeast in urine and
   sputum. MRSA screen pos.
   - C. diff negative [**4-25**]
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn started [**4-22**] given initial decompensation. (Day 7
   today)
   - Started fluconazole yesterday for positive B-glucan
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   ..
   # Hypernatremia: was resolving, however borderline high again in the
   setting of restarting tube feeds.
   - continue free water boluses to 250 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure:  Cr stable at 1.8
 2.0. Patient now
   adequately fluid resuscitated. FENa 1.26%, so likely not entirely
   pre-renal.
   - monitor Cr
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Currently in the high20s,
   stable x 3+ days.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional (LOS 15L positive).  He
   was noted to be anemic with guaiac positive stools during last
   admission.  B12,  folate, & iron  within normal limits (though ferritin
   may be elevated as an acute phase reactant and should be rechecked).
   [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT. INR therapeutic at 2.1.
   - Cont warfarin
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone and fluconazole
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  Rec'd one dose of
   vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  CT abdomen showing
   no drainable fluid collection
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn Day [**8-16**] (started [**4-22**]) for broad spectrum
   coverage in the absence of specific microbio data; also started Fluc
   yesterday
   - [**Doctor First Name 3**] recs: OK to feed; TF started [**4-24**]
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, TF with incr free water flushes
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with warfarin, lansoprazole,
   bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from last admission; will not d/c at this time
   since other sites are inaccessible due to large clots), A-line; Will
   pull R fem CVC today as amio has now been converted from gtt to PO.
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, HCP [**Name (NI) 4955**] [**Name (NI) 4961**] (neighbor; number in
   chart); will discuss possible need for trach/peg in the future
   .

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 81-year-old male with a complex medical history, including lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is tolerating PSV well, but has poor NIF and anxiety level, which are barriers to extubation. He is on mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 40% and a PEEP of 5 cmH2O.
* Hemodynamics: The patient has atrial fibrillation with RVR, which is likely due to septic state. He has a mixed venous O2 saturation of 28.5%, suggesting distributive shock. His heart rate has decreased from 110s-130s to 90-100s after transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells.
* Abdominal pain: The patient's abdominal pain is difficult to assess due to his altered sensorium. He has been stooling well, and his C. diff test is negative. However, he has a history of medically managed ruptured appendicitis, and his abdominal pain is worrisome.
* Fever: The patient's fever may be due to aspiration pneumonitis from intubation, occult infectious process, or worsening of his ruptured appendicitis. He has a B-glucan floridly positive (>500), which is not surprising given his prolonged antibiotic courses and frequent hospital stays.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia is resolving, but it is still borderline high. He is receiving free water boluses to 250 cc q4h.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's creatinine is stable at 1.8-2.0, and his FENa is 1.26%, suggesting that his renal failure is not entirely pre-renal.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia is stable at around 37, and it is likely partially dilutional due to his recent fluid resuscitation. His B12, folate, and iron levels are within normal limits, but his ferritin level may be elevated as an acute phase reactant.
* Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient has significant erythema and edema of his right upper extremity, and he is on lovenox and coumadin for bridge therapy.
* Ruptured appendicitis: The patient has been on Cipro/flagyl for medical management of his ruptured appendicitis, and he has been afebrile and leukopenic. His CT abdomen is negative for any drainable fluid collection.
* Pancreatic mass: The patient's pancreatic mass is stable on repeat imaging.
* Prophylaxis: The patient is receiving systemic anticoagulation with warfarin, lansoprazole, and bowel regimen.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen if he does not tolerate extubation, or if his underlying lung disease worsens.
* Hemodynamic instability: The patient's hemodynamic instability can worsen if his septic state worsens, or if he develops cardiogenic shock.
* Abdominal pain: The patient's abdominal pain can worsen if he develops peritonitis or abscesses.
* Fever: The patient's fever can worsen if he develops a superimposed infection, or if his underlying condition worsens.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia can worsen if he does not receive adequate fluid resuscitation.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's renal failure can worsen if he does not receive adequate fluid resuscitation, or if he develops acute tubular necrosis.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia can worsen if he does not receive adequate transfusion support.
* Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient's venous thrombosis can worsen if he develops pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis.
* Ruptured appendicitis: The patient's ruptured appendicitis can worsen if he develops peritonitis or abscesses.
* Pancreatic mass: The patient's pancreatic mass can worsen if he develops pancreatitis or pancreatic abscesses.

Based on the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to continue to monitor his vital signs, respiratory status, and hemodynamic stability closely. He should also receive aggressive fluid resuscitation to prevent hypernatremia and acute on chronic renal failure. Additionally, he should receive prophylactic anticoagulation to prevent venous thrombosis and prophylactic antibiotics to prevent sepsis.

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) who was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR). He was intubated for respiratory failure and is currently on mechanical ventilation. The patient has a complex medical history, including a ruptured appendix, which was medically managed, and is currently on antibiotics for suspected sepsis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he requires close monitoring to prevent further deterioration. Weaning off the ventilator will be challenging, and the patient may require prolonged mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated B-glucan levels and positive fungal cultures suggest the possibility of sepsis. He is already on antibiotics, but further evaluation and treatment are necessary to address this potential complication.
3. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are still elevated, and he requires continued free water boluses to manage this condition.
4. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are stable, but his renal function is still compromised. He requires close monitoring of his renal function and adjustment of his medication dosages accordingly.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely related to chronic kidney disease (CKD) and may require further evaluation and treatment.
6. Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient has a significant thrombosis in his right subclavian vein, which requires anticoagulation therapy.
7. Ruptured appendicitis: The patient's ruptured appendix was medically managed, but he may require further evaluation and treatment to ensure that the infection has been fully resolved.
8. Pancreatic mass: The patient has a pancreatic mass that requires ongoing evaluation and management.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient requires ongoing close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiac, and renal function. He requires continued antibiotics for suspected sepsis, and his hypernatremia requires ongoing free water boluses. His anemia requires further evaluation and treatment, and his thrombosis requires anticoagulation therapy. The patient's ruptured appendix and pancreatic mass require ongoing evaluation and management.

   Assessment and PlanThis is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p
   resection, prostate ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD,
   SVT, CHF and ruptured appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with
   hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for
   respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). Tolerating PS better each
   day, although RSBI was 158 early this morning.
   - Continue PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Repeat RSBI/NIF
   daily-[**Hospital1 **]. (RSBI 90-100 and NIF -18 during rounds)
   - Barriers to extubation: anxiety level, poor NIF (weakness).
   - OOB into chair today (PT consult)
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Was transfused 2 u pRBCs 3/24 per
   Cardiology who felt pt was intravascularly volume depleted, and HR came
   down from 110s-130s to 90-100s. Echo highly suspicious for PE, however
   pt already systemically anticoagulated and renal failure precludes CTA
   chest.
   - Appreciate cardiology recs. On PO amio now with rate mostly in
   90s-110s.
   - On very low dose levophed at this time (0.02 mcg/kg/min); suspect
   will be able to wean it off completely once all sedation is lifted.
   - No lasix at this time as pt auto-diuresing post-ATN
   .
   # Abdominal pain: difficult to assess as pt
s sensorium is not
   completely clear, however it
s worrisome given his history of medically
   managed ruptured appendicitis. Pt is stooling well (1-3 times a day),
   C.diff neg x 1, and has no residuals with TF. KUB neg for ileus or
   obstruction. LFTs, amylase, lipase all WNL. Repeat C-diff pending.
   - Will hold off on further investigation for now; talk to patient once
   extubated for better history. The next step would be CT of abdomen and
   pelvis.
   - Continue TF as tolerating well with no residuals.
   .
   # Fever: Patient had been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. other occult infectious
   process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC count and
   has been afebrile x 72+ hours. Pt may not be able to mount a robust
   inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically ill
   state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. B-glucan floridly
   positive (>500) which is not surprising given pt
s prolonged abx
   courses, frequent hospital stays and h/o TPN. Yeast in urine and
   sputum. MRSA screen pos.
   - C. diff negative [**4-25**]; repeat pending
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn started [**4-22**] given initial decompensation. (Day 8
   today)
   - On day 3 of fluconazole which was started for positive B-glucan (Day
   3 today)
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   ..
   # Hypernatremia: better with D5W x 1L yesterday.
   - hold off on further D5W infusions; give PRN after checking PM lytes
   - continue free water boluses to 250 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure:  Resolving. Cr better this morning at
   1.6. UOP very good with likely post-ATN diuresis.
   - monitor Cr
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Currently in the high20s,
   stable after 2 u pRBCs on [**4-26**].   B12,  folate, & iron  within normal
   limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase reactant and
   should be rechecked once pt recovers from acute illness).  [**Month (only) 11**] be
   partially related to CKD. Also having low grade hematuria (pink urine)
   off and on (with anticoagulation/INR 2.2)
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   - monitor hematuria
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now on coumadin
   with INR therapeutic 2.2 today (goal [**3-8**]). Left arm without any DVT.
   - Cont warfarin
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone and fluconazole
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  Rec'd one dose of
   vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  CT abdomen showing
   no drainable fluid collection
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn Day [**9-16**] (started [**4-22**]) for broad spectrum
   coverage in the absence of specific microbio data; also started Fluc on
   [**4-27**] for + B-glucan
   - TF started [**4-24**]
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, TF with free water flushes
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with warfarin, lansoprazole,
   bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from last admission; will not d/c at this time
   since other sites are inaccessible due to large clots), A-line; R fem
   CVC pulled yesterday.
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, HCP [**Name (NI) 4955**] [**Name (NI) 4961**] (neighbor; number in
   chart)
   .
   # Disposition: requires ICU level of care while intubated

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix, who was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular rate (RVR). He was intubated for respiratory failure and has been receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient's condition has been complicated by acute kidney injury, sepsis, and pancreatitis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute and a respiratory system resistance of 158. He is at risk for further respiratory decline and potential respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's white blood cell count is within normal limits, but he has a high B-glucan level, which suggests the presence of fungal infection. He is at risk for further sepsis and potential organ dysfunction.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level has improved, but he is at risk for further kidney damage and potential chronic kidney disease.
4. Pancreatitis: The patient has a history of pancreatic mass and pancreatitis, which may be exacerbated by his current condition.
5. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's atrial fibrillation with RVR is a significant concern, and he is at risk for further cardiovascular instability and potential cardiac arrest.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level has improved, but he is at risk for further electrolyte imbalances and potential complications.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of ruptured appendix and is at risk for further gastrointestinal bleeding and potential complications.
8. Infection: The patient has a positive MRSA screen and is at risk for further infection and potential complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and adjust respiratory settings as needed to maintain optimal respiratory function.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status closely and adjust medications as needed to manage atrial fibrillation and RVR.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust fluid management accordingly to prevent further electrolyte imbalances.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust medications as needed to manage acute kidney injury.
5. Consider further imaging studies to evaluate the patient's pancreatic mass and pancreatitis.
6. Consider further infection control measures to prevent further infection and potential complications.
7. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status closely and adjust medications as needed to manage potential gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. Consider further consultation with specialists, such as cardiology and gastroenterology, to optimize the patient's care.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health status as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient has persistent respiratory failure, with tolerance to PSV at 12/5 with a respiratory rate of 28-30. The patient's respiratory compromise is primarily due to muscle weakness, which will be evaluated through repeat NIF testing.
* Sepsis/Hypotension: The patient has sepsis with persistent hypotension, and cultures remain negative. Fever is controlled, and the patient is receiving antibiotics (Zosyn/Vanco) and vasopressor support (Levophed).
* Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which is well-controlled with Amiodarone. The patient is also anticoagulated for other reasons.
* DVT: The patient has a DVT, and Coumadin is being used as anticoagulation given the extensive clot.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: Prolonged respiratory failure can lead to further muscle weakness, respiratory acidosis, and potential cardiac complications.
2. Sepsis/Hypotension: Prolonged sepsis and hypotension can lead to multi-organ dysfunction, including kidney, liver, and cardiovascular failure.
3. Atrial Fibrillation: Uncontrolled atrial fibrillation can lead to cardiac complications, such as stroke, heart failure, and arrhythmias.
4. DVT: Prolonged DVT can lead to pulmonary embolism, which can be life-threatening.
5. Muscle weakness: Prolonged muscle weakness can lead to respiratory failure, difficulty with weaning from the ventilator, and potential cardiac complications.

To mitigate these complications, the patient's treatment plan should focus on:

1. Improving respiratory function through weaning from the ventilator, minimizing sedation, and using fentanyl patch for pain management.
2. Managing sepsis and hypotension through continued antibiotic and vasopressor support, as well as monitoring for signs of multi-organ dysfunction.
3. Controlling atrial fibrillation through continued Amiodarone therapy and anticoagulation.
4. Managing DVT through continued anticoagulation with Coumadin.
5. Monitoring for signs of muscle weakness and respiratory failure, and adjusting the treatment plan accordingly.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). Tolerating PS better each
   day, although RSBI was 158 early this morning.
   - Continue PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Repeat RSBI/NIF
   daily-[**Hospital1 **]. (RSBI 90-100 and NIF -18 during rounds)
   - Barriers to extubation: anxiety level, poor NIF (weakness).
   - OOB into chair today (PT consult)
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Was transfused 2 u pRBCs 3/24 per
   Cardiology who felt pt was intravascularly volume depleted, and HR came
   down from 110s-130s to 90-100s. Echo highly suspicious for PE, however
   pt already systemically anticoagulated and renal failure precludes CTA
   chest.
   - Appreciate cardiology recs. On PO amio now with rate mostly in
   90s-110s.
   - On very low dose levophed at this time (0.02 mcg/kg/min); suspect
   will be able to wean it off completely once all sedation is lifted.
   - No lasix at this time as pt auto-diuresing post-ATN
   .
   # Abdominal pain: difficult to assess as pt
s sensorium is not
   completely clear, however it
s worrisome given his history of medically
   managed ruptured appendicitis. Pt is stooling well (1-3 times a day),
   C.diff neg x 1, and has no residuals with TF. KUB neg for ileus or
   obstruction. LFTs, amylase, lipase all WNL. Repeat C-diff pending.
   - Will hold off on further investigation for now; talk to patient once
   extubated for better history. The next step would be CT of abdomen and
   pelvis.
   - Continue TF as tolerating well with no residuals.
   .
   # Fever: Patient had been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. other occult infectious
   process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC count and
   has been afebrile x 72+ hours. Pt may not be able to mount a robust
   inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically ill
   state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. B-glucan floridly
   positive (>500) which is not surprising given pt
s prolonged abx
   courses, frequent hospital stays and h/o TPN. Yeast in urine and
   sputum. MRSA screen pos.
   - C. diff negative [**4-25**]; repeat pending
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn started [**4-22**] given initial decompensation. (Day 8
   today)
   - On day 3 of fluconazole which was started for positive B-glucan (Day
   3 today)
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   ..
   # Hypernatremia: better with D5W x 1L yesterday.
   - hold off on further D5W infusions; give PRN after checking PM lytes
   - continue free water boluses to 250 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure:  Resolving. Cr better this morning at
   1.6. UOP very good with likely post-ATN diuresis.
   - monitor Cr
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Currently in the high20s,
   stable after 2 u pRBCs on [**4-26**].   B12,  folate, & iron  within normal
   limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase reactant and
   should be rechecked once pt recovers from acute illness).  [**Month (only) 11**] be
   partially related to CKD. Also having low grade hematuria (pink urine)
   off and on (with anticoagulation/INR 2.2)
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   - monitor hematuria
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now on coumadin
   with INR therapeutic 2.2 today (goal [**3-8**]). Left arm without any DVT.
   - Cont warfarin
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone and fluconazole
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  Rec'd one dose of
   vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  CT abdomen showing
   no drainable fluid collection
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn Day [**9-16**] (started [**4-22**]) for broad spectrum
   coverage in the absence of specific microbio data; also started Fluc on
   [**4-27**] for + B-glucan
   - TF started [**4-24**]
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, TF with free water flushes
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with warfarin, lansoprazole,
   bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from last admission; will not d/c at this time
   since other sites are inaccessible due to large clots), A-line; R fem
   CVC pulled yesterday.
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, HCP [**Name (NI) 4955**] [**Name (NI) 4961**] (neighbor; number in
   chart)
   .
   # Disposition: requires ICU level of care while intubated

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation, which may lead to complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), respiratory failure, and difficulty weaning off the ventilator.
2. Atrial fibrillation with RVR: The patient's atrial fibrillation with RVR is likely related to septic shock, and may lead to further complications such as cardiac arrest, stroke, and heart failure.
3. Abdominal pain: The patient's abdominal pain may be related to the ruptured appendix, and may worsen if not properly managed. Further investigation, such as a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis, may be necessary to rule out complications such as ileus, obstruction, or abscesses.
4. Fever: The patient's fever may be related to aspiration pneumonitis, occult infectious process, or worsening of the ruptured appendix. Further evaluation, such as blood cultures and imaging studies, may be necessary to determine the cause of the fever.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may be related to the administration of D5W, and may lead to complications such as seizures, cerebral edema, and electrolyte imbalances.
6. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure may worsen if not properly managed, leading to complications such as electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and end-stage renal disease.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be related to chronic kidney disease, and may worsen if not properly managed, leading to complications such as fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased cognitive function.
8. Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient's right subclavian vein thrombosis may lead to complications such as pulmonary embolism, deep vein thrombosis, and post-thrombotic syndrome.
9. Ruptured appendicitis: The patient's ruptured appendicitis may lead to complications such as peritonitis, abscesses, and sepsis.
10. Pancreatic mass: The patient's pancreatic mass may be related to pancreatic cancer, and may lead to complications such as pancreatic ductal obstruction, pancreatic ascites, and metastatic disease.

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, it is essential to continue to monitor and manage these potential complications closely to prevent further deterioration and improve the patient's outcomes.

   C. diff neg x 2
   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16).   Patient tolerated PSV this
   morning with NIF +28.
   - attempt extubation today
   - Barriers to extubation: anxiety level, poor NIF (weakness).
   - OOB into chair today (PT consult)
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Was transfused 2 u pRBCs 3/24 per
   Cardiology who felt pt was intravascularly volume depleted, and HR came
   down from 110s-130s to 90-100s. Echo highly suspicious for PE, however
   pt already systemically anticoagulated and renal failure precludes CTA
   chest.  Levophed off.
   - Appreciate cardiology recs. On PO amio now with rate mostly in
   90s-110s.
   - No lasix at this time as pt auto-diuresing post-ATN
   - pt. was on metoprolol as an outpatient for rate control, can consider
   restarting as BP improves
   .
   # Fever: Patient had been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis with course to end on [**4-22**].  Fever may represent
   worsening of this process vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation
   vs. other occult infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not
   have an elevated WBC count and has been afebrile x 72+ hours. Pt may
   not be able to mount a robust inflammatory response due to older age
   and general chronically ill state. CT negative for any drainable
   abscesses. B-glucan floridly positive (>500) which is not surprising
   given pt
s prolonged abx courses, frequent hospital stays and h/o TPN.
   Yeast in urine and sputum. MRSA screen pos.
   - C. diff negative x 2
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn started [**4-22**] given initial decompensation. (Day 9
   today). Plan for 10 day total course
   - On day 4 of fluconazole which was started for positive B-glucan (D1 =
   [**4-27**]).  Plan for 7 day course?
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   .
   # Abdominal pain: Absent today.  Previously was difficult to assess as
   pt
s sensorium was not completely clear, however it was worrisome given
   his history of medically managed ruptured appendicitis. Pt is stooling
   well (1-3 times a day), C.diff neg x 2, and has no residuals with TF.
   KUB neg for ileus or obstruction. LFTs, amylase, lipase all WNL.
   - Will hold off on further investigation for now; talk to patient once
   extubated for better history. The next step would be CT of abdomen and
   pelvis.
   - Continue TF as tolerating well with no residuals.
   .
   # Hypernatremia: better with D5W.
   - hold off on further D5W infusions; give PRN after checking PM lytes
   - continue free water boluses to 250 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure:  Resolving. Cr better this morning at
   1.3. UOP very good with likely post-ATN diuresis.
   - monitor Cr
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Currently in the high20s,
   stable after 2 u pRBCs on [**4-26**].   B12,  folate, & iron  within normal
   limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase reactant and
   should be rechecked once pt recovers from acute illness).  [**Month (only) 11**] be
   partially related to CKD. Also having low grade hematuria (pink urine)
   off and on (with anticoagulation/INR 2.2)
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   - monitor hematuria
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now on coumadin
   with INR therapeutic 2.0 today (goal [**3-8**]). Left arm without any DVT.
   - increase warfarin again to 2.5 mg as INR barely therapeutic
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone and fluconazole
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  Rec'd one dose of
   vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  CT abdomen showing
   no drainable fluid collection
   - Vanc/zosyn and fluconazole as above
   - TF started [**4-24**]
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, TF with free water flushes held pending
   extubation.  Will try on clears later today if successfully extubated
   and has a good gag.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with warfarin, lansoprazole,
   bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from last admission; will not d/c at this time
   since other sites are inaccessible due to large clots), A-line; R fem
   CVC pulled [**4-28**].
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, HCP [**Name (NI) 4955**] [**Name (NI) 4961**] (neighbor; number in
   chart)
   .
   # Disposition: requires ICU level of care, if does well post
   extubation, potential c/o to floor tomorrow.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   PICC Line - [**2107-4-21**] 05:00 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2107-4-22**] 10:58 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
